title: Add Japanese Yen (JPY) Currency Display Support
bodyText:
Overview
This PR adds support for displaying Claude Code usage costs in Japanese Yen (JPY) alongside the existing USD display. Users can now switch between USD and JPY with a persistent preference that is maintained across sessions.
Changes
Main Changes

Currency Conversion: Implemented JPY support with a fixed conversion rate of 1 USD = 150 JPY
Persistent Configuration: Added configuration storage using the conf library for cross-platform support
CLI Enhancement: Added --currency flag to all commands for easy currency switching
Number Formatting: Improved number formatting with comma separators for better readability

Technical Details

Modified Files:

utils.ts - Updated formatCurrency() to support multiple currencies
commands/daily.ts & commands/session.ts - Integrated currency-aware formatting
shared-args.ts - Added --currency CLI argument
README.md - Added currency feature documentation


New Files:

config.ts - Configuration management module
currency.ts - Currency conversion and formatting logic
config.test.ts & currency.test.ts - Comprehensive test coverage


Dependencies:

Added conf@13.1.0 for configuration storage
Added @types/conf@3.0.3 for TypeScript support


Configuration:

Config stored in platform-specific locations (macOS/Linux: ~/.config/ccusage/config.json, Windows: %APPDATA%\ccusage\config.json)



Impact

Breaking Changes: No - Existing functionality remains unchanged, USD is still the default
Database Changes: No
API Changes: No - JSON output format remains unchanged (always shows USD values)
Performance Impact: Negligible - Only adds configuration file read on startup

Testing

 Unit tests pass
 Integration tests pass
 Manual testing completed
 Performance testing (not applicable)

Test Details

Added 13 new tests covering currency conversion, formatting, and configuration persistence
Updated existing tests to support the new formatCurrency signature
All 47 tests pass successfully
Test coverage includes:

USD to JPY conversion accuracy
Number formatting with comma separators
Currency symbol display ($ vs Â¥)
Decimal place handling (2 for USD, 0 for JPY)
Configuration persistence across sessions
Invalid currency handling



Deployment

Special Instructions: None - the feature is self-contained
Environment Variables: None required
Migration Steps: None - configuration is created automatically on first use

Review Focus Areas

Currency Conversion Rate: Currently hardcoded at 1 USD = 150 JPY - is this acceptable or should it be configurable?
Number Formatting: Using toLocaleString('en-US') for both currencies - should JPY use a different locale?
Configuration Location: Using the conf library's default paths - are these appropriate for the project?

Related Information

Issue/Ticket: Not linked to a specific issue
Documentation: README.md updated with currency configuration section
Screenshots:

Example output with JPY display:

title: feat: Debug Features and Cost Calculation Modes types to log function
bodyText:
fixes: #4 #3
This pull request introduces significant enhancements to the cost calculation functionality, updates to the schema for usage data, and improvements to testing and debugging capabilities. The most important changes include adding support for cost calculation modes, integrating LiteLLM pricing data, expanding the schema for usage data, and refining session data handling.
Cost Calculation Enhancements:

Added three cost calculation modes (auto, calculate, display) to control how costs are computed based on token counts or pre-calculated costUSD values. ([[1]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-6ebdb617a8104a7756d0cf36578ab01103dc9f07e4dc6feb751296b9c402faf7R22-R30), [[2]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5R116-R120), [[3]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5R141-R145), [[4]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-b335630551682c19a781afebcf4d07bf978fb1f8ac04c6bf87428ed5106870f5R156-R165))
Implemented logic to calculate costs dynamically using LiteLLM pricing data when the mode is set to calculate or fallback to auto mode. ([[1]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcR91-R93), [[2]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcL108-R155), [[3]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcL153-R200), [[4]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcR238-R287))

LiteLLM Integration:

Integrated LiteLLM's pricing database to fetch model-specific pricing data for cost calculations. ([[1]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-6ebdb617a8104a7756d0cf36578ab01103dc9f07e4dc6feb751296b9c402faf7R53), [[2]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcR91-R93), [[3]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcL108-R155))
Added validation to ensure model names in tests match LiteLLM's database entries to prevent failures caused by unsupported models. ([CLAUDE.mdR63-R86](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-6ebdb617a8104a7756d0cf36578ab01103dc9f07e4dc6feb751296b9c402faf7R63-R86))

Schema Updates:

Expanded the UsageDataSchema and SessionUsageSchema to include optional fields for model names and versions, enabling more detailed tracking of usage data. ([[1]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcR7-R29), [[2]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcR54))
Enhanced session data handling to include unique versions used within a session and sort results by last activity instead of total cost. ([[1]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcL153-R200), [[2]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-9ef087b6a8799e1e3852522a758149979ace890a62c820a6d12a36e3eb7cc5fcL215-R303))

Debugging and Testing Improvements:

Added debugging utilities (detectMismatches, printMismatchReport) to identify discrepancies in data and provide detailed reports. ([[1]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-a22e1a0044d16770257ddea66c38e5d9a02b67ee541793687e483fce477e5835R11-R26), [[2]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-a22e1a0044d16770257ddea66c38e5d9a02b67ee541793687e483fce477e5835R42-R47), [[3]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-6f9669bd0d0825f4042a8b411bc063f5a8df5d557c7421b91ffb72c5ceb75c26R11-R26), [[4]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-6f9669bd0d0825f4042a8b411bc063f5a8df5d557c7421b91ffb72c5ceb75c26R42-R47))
Updated testing guidelines to ensure comprehensive coverage for supported Claude 4 models and compatibility with LiteLLM pricing data. ([[1]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-6ebdb617a8104a7756d0cf36578ab01103dc9f07e4dc6feb751296b9c402faf7R63-R86), [[2]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-8154d3524d88625e7af075f901b613ca1232ec13895d54b8c0fd3c0796f1aeccR49), [[3]](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/5/files#diff-8154d3524d88625e7af075f901b613ca1232ec13895d54b8c0fd3c0796f1aeccR60))

title: chore: move files under src directory
bodyText:
fixes: #2
This pull request introduces several updates to the project structure, including changes to file paths, package scripts, and configuration settings. The most significant updates involve reorganizing the codebase to use a src directory for source files, modifying import paths, and adjusting package scripts to reflect the new structure.
Updates to project structure:

Reorganization of source files:

Renamed index.ts to src/commands/index.ts and adjusted imports to reflect the new directory structure. ([src/commands/index.tsL1-R5](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/7/files#diff-a6a1db61476382a80351bf0b40126b3cfca87878293a3fca70dfe04367f4a11fL1-R5))
Added a new src/index.ts file as the entry point, including a shebang for CLI execution and importing src/commands/index.ts. ([src/index.tsR1-R3](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/7/files#diff-a2a171449d862fe29692ce031981047d7ab755ae7f84c707aef80701b3ea0c80R1-R3))
Renamed logger.ts to src/logger.ts and updated the import path for package.json. ([src/logger.tsL3-R3](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/7/files#diff-7bc1140e724e284ae22084e1172568baa8d151063d02c75ed1d8805fa7796acaL3-R3))



Updates to package.json:

Exports additions:

Added new entries for ./debug, ./logger, ./pricing-fetcher, ./shared-args, ./types, and ./utils in the exports field. ([package.jsonR21-R26](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/7/files#diff-7ae45ad102eab3b6d7e7896acd08c427a9b25b346470d7bc6507b6481575d519R21-R26))


Script modifications:

Replaced the report script with a start script that runs ./src/index.ts. ([package.jsonL35-R41](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/7/files#diff-7ae45ad102eab3b6d7e7896acd08c427a9b25b346470d7bc6507b6481575d519L35-R41))



Updates to configuration:

Build entry points:

Updated the tsdown.config.ts file to use ./src/*.ts as entry points, excluding test files (!./src/**/*.test.ts). ([tsdown.config.tsL5-R5](https://github.com/ryoppippi/ccusage/pull/7/files#diff-c105f99c241d6d60e41561e663ee096629894e9b2a773c82283655b323f59485L5-R5))

title: feat: implement mcp
bodyText:
This pull request introduces support for the Model Context Protocol (MCP) to enable usage data integration with external tools. It adds a new mcp command, updates the package configuration, and implements the MCP server with features for usage reporting. Below are the most important changes grouped by theme:
MCP Command Integration:

Added a new mcp command in src/commands/mcp.ts to start the MCP server with configurable transport types (stdio or http) and modes (calculate, display, or auto). This command integrates with shared arguments and supports HTTP port configuration.
Updated src/commands/index.ts to include the mcpCommand in the subcommands map, enabling the use of the new MCP functionality.

MCP Server Implementation:

Created the createMcpServer function in src/mcp.ts to initialize a FastMCP server with tools for generating daily and session usage reports. It uses schemas for parameter validation and supports cost calculation modes.

Documentation Updates:

Updated README.md with a detailed section on MCP support, including usage examples, transport options, and configuration instructions for integration with tools like Claude Desktop.

Package Configuration:

Added ./mcp export to package.json for the MCP module and included new dependencies @valibot/to-json-schema and fastmcp for schema validation and MCP server implementation. [1] [2]

title: feat: add multi-currency support with live exchange rates
bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds comprehensive multi-currency support to ccusage, allowing users to view Claude usage costs in their preferred currency with live exchange rates.
Key Features

ğŸŒ 20 Supported Currencies: USD, EUR, GBP, JPY, CAD, AUD, CHF, CNY, INR, IDR, SGD, HKD, KRW, MXN, BRL, ZAR, SEK, NOK, DKK, PLN
ğŸ“¡ Live Exchange Rates: Fetches current rates from exchangerate-api.com
âš¡ Smart Caching: 2-hour local cache in ~/.claude/exchange-rates.json for performance
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Graceful Fallbacks: Falls back to USD if API fails or currency unavailable
ğŸ’± Proper Formatting: Currency-specific symbols and decimal handling (e.g., IDR shows "Rp", JPY shows no decimals)
ğŸ”§ CLI Integration: New --currency/-c flag works with all existing commands

Usage Examples
# Daily report in Indonesian Rupiah
ccusage daily --currency IDR

# Session report in Euros with JSON output
ccusage session --currency EUR --json

# British Pounds with date filtering
ccusage daily --currency GBP --since 20250101
Technical Implementation
Core Components:

CurrencyService: Handles exchange rate fetching, caching, and conversion
ExchangeRate interface: Type-safe currency data structure
convertCostToCurrency(): Utility function for USDâ†’target conversion
Enhanced CLI args with currency validation

Architecture Decisions:

Internal calculations remain in USD (maintains LiteLLM compatibility)
Currency conversion only at display time (preserves data integrity)
Local file-based caching for offline resilience
Free API with no rate limits or registration required

Error Handling:

Network failures â†’ fallback to stale cache â†’ fallback to USD
Missing currencies â†’ fallback to USD with warning
Invalid cache files â†’ start with empty cache

Files Added/Modified
New Files:

src/currency.ts - Core currency service implementation
src/currency.test.ts - Comprehensive test coverage

Modified Files:

src/types.ts - Currency types and validation schemas
src/shared-args.ts - CLI argument definition
src/calculate-cost.ts - Currency conversion utilities
src/commands/daily.ts - Multi-currency table/JSON output
src/commands/session.ts - Multi-currency table/JSON output

Testing
âœ… Comprehensive test coverage for CurrencyService including:

Exchange rate fetching with API mocking
Caching behavior and TTL validation
Error handling and fallback scenarios
Currency formatting and symbol handling

âœ… Manual testing verified:

CLI flag recognition and validation
Live API integration with caching
Proper formatting in both table and JSON outputs
Graceful handling of network failures

Example Output
Table Format (IDR):

      "currency": "EUR"

    "totalCost": 76.77,
    "currency": "EUR"
  }
}
Backward Compatibility
âœ… Fully backward compatible - defaults to USD if no currency specified
âœ… No breaking changes to existing CLI interface or JSON structure
âœ… Maintains data integrity - all internal calculations still in USD
Test Plan

 Verify CLI flag appears in help output
 Test currency conversion with live API
 Validate caching behavior and TTL expiration
 Confirm fallback handling for network errors
 Test all 20 supported currencies
 Verify table and JSON output formatting
 Check backward compatibility with no --currency flag
 Validate proper currency symbols and decimal handling

Implementation Notes
This feature enables international users to better understand their Claude Code usage costs in familiar currencies. The implementation prioritizes reliability with multiple fallback layers and maintains full backward compatibility.
The exchange rate API (exchangerate-api.com) is free, reliable, and doesn't require registration, making it ideal for this use case. Local caching ensures good performance and offline functionality.

title: feat: add monthly report and --date-sort sorting for daily/monthly reports
bodyText:
Add Date Sorting and Monthly Report Features
This PR combines two related features that enhance ccusage's reporting capabilities:
ğŸš€ Features Added
1. Date Sorting for Reports (--date-sort)

Adds --date-sort flag to control report ordering
Options: desc (newest first, default) or asc (oldest first)
Applies to both daily and monthly reports
Helps users analyze trends chronologically or see most recent data first

2. Monthly Usage Report (ccusage monthly)

New command that aggregates usage by month (YYYY-MM format)
Provides higher-level view of usage trends over time
Supports all features from daily report:

Table and JSON output formats
Cost calculation modes (auto/calculate/display)
Date filtering (--since/--until)
Date sorting (--date-sort asc/desc)



ğŸ“‹ Implementation Details

Daily sorting: Modified loadUsageData() to respect dateSort parameter
Monthly report: Created new monthly.ts command with aggregateByMonth() function
Ensured feature parity between daily and monthly commands
Added comprehensive tests for all new functionality
Updated documentation

ğŸ§ª Testing

âœ… All existing tests pass
âœ… Added tests for date sorting (ascending/descending)
âœ… Added tests for monthly aggregation
âœ… Added tests for year boundary handling
âœ… Manual testing of all command combinations

ğŸ’¡ Why Combine These PRs?
Initially, I implemented just the daily sorting feature. However, after implementing the monthly report, it became clear that both features should support sorting for consistency. Rather than having the monthly report lack sorting capabilities, I've combined both features to ensure a complete, consistent implementation.
Closes #10 (Monthly report feature)
Closes #11 (Add ascending/descending sort order)

title: feat: add monthly usage report command
bodyText:
feat: add monthly usage report command
ğŸ“‹ Summary
This PR implements a new monthly subcommand that aggregates Claude Code token usage and costs by month (YYYY-MM format), providing users with a higher-level view of their usage trends over time.
The implementation maintains full feature parity with the existing daily command while following the established codebase patterns and conventions.
Closes #10
ğŸ¯ Motivation
Users tracking their Claude Code usage often need to view trends at different granularities. While the daily report is excellent for detailed analysis, a monthly view helps identify:

Long-term usage patterns
Month-over-month cost trends
Seasonal variations in AI assistant usage
Budget planning insights

ğŸš€ Implementation Details
Core Features

Monthly Aggregation: Groups daily usage data by month (YYYY-MM format)
Descending Sort: Displays most recent months first for better UX
Full Feature Parity: Supports all existing report features:

Table and JSON output formats (--json)
Three cost calculation modes (--mode auto|calculate|display)
Date range filtering (--since and --until)
Debug information (--debug)
Custom Claude data paths (--path)



Technical Approach

Created src/commands/monthly.ts following the same structure as daily.ts
Implemented aggregateByMonth() function that:

Extracts YYYY-MM from daily date strings
Aggregates all token types and costs
Returns sorted array of monthly usage data


Reused existing utilities for token calculations and formatting
Maintained consistent UI/UX with other commands

Code Quality

âœ… TypeScript strict mode compliance
âœ… Biome linting and formatting
âœ… Unit tests for aggregation logic
âœ… Documentation updates in README and CLAUDE.md

title: feat: refactor schema to use regex for date and month
bodyText:
This pull request improves the validation of date and month fields in the src/data-loader.ts file by introducing stricter regex-based validation for formatting. The changes ensure that these fields conform to expected formats (YYYY-MM-DD for dates and YYYY-MM for months).
Validation improvements:

src/data-loader.ts: Updated DailyUsageSchema to validate the date field using a regex pattern that enforces the YYYY-MM-DD format.
src/data-loader.ts: Updated MonthlyUsageSchema to validate the month field using a regex pattern that enforces the YYYY-MM format.

title: feat: add sort order support
bodyText:
Add Sort Order Support for Daily and Monthly Reports
Feature #11
Summary
This PR adds a new --order (-o) flag to control the sort order of dates in both daily and monthly usage reports. Users can now choose between descending (newest first, default) and ascending (oldest first) order, providing more flexibility in how they view their Claude usage data.
Motivation
Previously, both daily and monthly reports were hard-coded to display dates in descending order (newest first). While this is often the desired behavior, some users may prefer to see their usage chronologically from oldest to newest, especially when:

Tracking usage growth over time
Analyzing historical trends
Comparing early usage patterns with recent ones
Generating reports for documentation that should read chronologically

Implementation Details
Changes Made


Added --order flag to shared arguments (src/shared-args.ts)

Short flag: -o
Long flag: --order
Choices: desc (default) or asc
Consistent naming between short and long forms for intuitive CLI usage



Extended LoadOptions interface (src/data-loader.ts)

Added optional order?: "desc" | "asc" property
Maintains backward compatibility with default "desc" behavior



Updated sorting logic in data loaders

loadDailyUsageData: Sorts daily entries based on the order parameter
loadMonthlyUsageData: Sorts monthly aggregations based on the order parameter
Refactored to use fast-sort consistently and eliminate code duplication



Updated command implementations

Both daily and monthly commands now pass the order option to their respective data loaders
No changes to output format or data structure



Comprehensive test coverage

Added tests for ascending order sorting in daily reports
Added tests for ascending order sorting in monthly reports
Added tests for explicit descending order (ensuring default behavior is preserved)
Added tests for year boundary handling in monthly sorting



Documentation updates

Updated README.md with the new -o, --order flag documentation
Clear explanation of the two sort options and their effects



Code Quality Improvements
During implementation, I also addressed a code review suggestion to reduce duplication in the sorting logic:

Extracted the sort() call into a variable to avoid calling it twice in conditional branches
Applied this pattern consistently in both daily and monthly sorting functions
Switched monthly sorting to use fast-sort library for consistency

Usage Examples
# Daily reports
ccusage daily -o asc          # Show oldest days first
ccusage daily -o desc         # Show newest days first (default)
ccusage daily                 # Same as -o desc

# Monthly reports  
ccusage monthly -o asc        # Show oldest months first
ccusage monthly -o desc       # Show newest months first (default)
ccusage monthly               # Same as -o desc

# Combined with other flags
ccusage daily -o asc -j       # JSON output with ascending order
ccusage monthly -o asc -s 20240101 -u 20241231  # Filter and sort
Testing
All existing tests pass, plus new tests added:

âœ… sorts by date ascending when order is 'asc' (daily)
âœ… sorts by date descending when order is 'desc' (daily)
âœ… sorts months in ascending order when order is 'asc' (monthly)
âœ… handles year boundaries correctly in sorting (monthly)

bun test           # All 100 tests pass
bun run lint       # No lint errors
bun typecheck      # No type errors
Breaking Changes
None. The default behavior remains unchanged (descending order), ensuring backward compatibility for existing users and scripts.
Future Considerations
This implementation provides a foundation for potential future enhancements:

Sort by other criteria (e.g., cost, token count)
Multi-level sorting options
Custom sort expressions

However, these are out of scope for this PR, which focuses on the immediate need for basic chronological ordering.
Screenshots

Daily report in ascending order
$ ccusage daily -o asc

bodyText:
This pull request removes references to the shared-args module from the project configuration files. The changes ensure that the module is no longer included in the build process or exported.

package.json: Removed the export entry for ./shared-args, which previously pointed to ./dist/shared-args.js.

title: stop exporting internal modules
bodyText:
This pull request focuses on restructuring the codebase by introducing the .internal.ts suffix for files intended for internal use and updating references accordingly. Additionally, it removes the utils export from package.json. These changes aim to improve code organization and clarify the separation between public and internal modules.
Code restructuring: .internal.ts suffix for internal modules

Renamed src/shared-args.ts to src/shared-args.internal.ts and updated all references to sharedCommandConfig and sharedArgs in src/commands/daily.ts, src/commands/mcp.ts, src/commands/monthly.ts, and src/commands/session.ts. [1] [2] [3] [4]
Renamed src/utils.test.ts to src/utils.internal.test.ts and updated the imports in the renamed file.
Updated imports for CostMode, SortOrder, CostModes, and dateSchema to use types.internal.ts instead of types.ts in multiple files (src/data-loader.ts, src/mcp.ts, src/shared-args.internal.ts). [1] [2] [3] [4]

Configuration updates

Modified tsdown.config.ts to exclude both .test.ts and .internal.ts files from the build output.

Removal of unused exports

Removed the utils export from package.json, as it is now considered an internal module.

title: feat: exhaustiveness check for union types
bodyText:
This pull request introduces several updates to improve code reliability, enforce stricter type safety, and enhance package management. The most important changes include adding the unreachable utility for exhaustive checks, refactoring sorting logic to use a switch statement, and updating package configurations.
Code reliability and type safety:

src/data-loader.ts: Added the unreachable utility from @core/errorutil to ensure exhaustive checks in calculateCostForEntry and loadDailyUsageData functions. This helps catch unexpected values for mode and sortOrder at runtime. [1] [2] [3]
src/data-loader.ts: Refactored sorting logic in loadDailyUsageData to use a switch statement for improved readability and to handle unexpected values more explicitly using the unreachable utility.

Package management:

.npmrc: Added a custom registry configuration for @jsr packages.
package.json: Updated devDependencies to include the @core/errorutil package for utility functions.

title: feat: class based pricing-fetcher with using syntax
bodyText:
This pull request refactors the cost calculation logic in the src/data-loader.ts, src/debug.ts, and associated test files to improve efficiency and maintainability. The key changes include replacing direct pricing cache manipulation with the PricingFetcher class, converting synchronous cost calculation functions to asynchronous, and ensuring proper cleanup of resources using the using statement.
Refactoring cost calculation logic:


Introduction of PricingFetcher class:

Replaced direct usage of pricing cache functions (clearPricingCache, fetchModelPricing, getModelPricing) with the PricingFetcher class across src/data-loader.ts and src/debug.ts. This encapsulates pricing logic and simplifies resource management. [1] [2]



Conversion to asynchronous cost calculation:

Updated calculateCostForEntry to an asynchronous function that uses PricingFetcher for token-based cost calculation. This ensures more flexibility and better handling of asynchronous operations. [1] [2] [3]



Resource management improvements:

Using statement for automatic cleanup:

Integrated the using statement to manage PricingFetcher instances in functions like loadDailyUsageData, loadSessionData, and detectMismatches. This ensures proper resource cleanup and avoids memory leaks. [1] [2] [3]



Test updates:

Refactoring tests to align with new logic:

Removed beforeEach blocks that cleared the pricing cache and updated test cases to use PricingFetcher instances for cost calculation. This ensures tests are consistent with the new implementation. [1] [2] [3]



These changes enhance the codebase by improving modularity, reducing direct dependency on pricing cache functions, and ensuring better resource management.

title: fix: implement chronological deduplication for branched conversations
bodyText:
Fix: Implement Chronological Deduplication for Branched Conversations
Summary
This PR fixes issue #19 by implementing a chronologically-aware deduplication system that prevents double-counting of tokens and costs when conversations are branched in Claude Code.
Fixes #19
Problem
When users branch conversations in Claude Code (by editing a past message with Esc+Esc), the application creates a new conversation that includes duplicate entries from the original conversation. These duplicates have identical requestId and message.id values, causing:

Inflated token counts - The same API calls are counted multiple times
Incorrect cost calculations - Users see higher costs than actually incurred
Wrong date attribution - Costs may be attributed to the branch date instead of the original date

Root Cause
The current implementation processes JSONL files in an undefined order (filesystem-dependent). This means:

A newer branched conversation file might be processed before the original
Without deduplication, both files contribute to the totals
Even with simple deduplication, processing order matters - the first processed entry "wins"

Solution
This PR implements a comprehensive deduplication solution that:
1. Chronological File Processing

Added getEarliestTimestamp() to extract the earliest timestamp from each JSONL file
Added sortFilesByTimestamp() to sort files by their earliest timestamp
Files are now processed oldest-first, ensuring original entries are preserved

2. Message Deduplication

Extended UsageDataSchema to include message.id and requestId fields
Added createUniqueHash() to generate unique identifiers from message+request IDs
Track processed hashes in a Set to skip duplicate entries
Implemented in both loadDailyUsageData() and loadSessionData()

3. Robust Implementation

Handles files without timestamps (placed at end of processing order)
Skips invalid JSON lines gracefully
Maintains backward compatibility with existing data

Testing
Added comprehensive test suite (data-loader-deduplication.test.ts) with 11 tests covering:

âœ… Hash creation from message and request IDs
âœ… Timestamp extraction from JSONL files
âœ… File sorting by timestamp
âœ… Deduplication in daily usage data
âœ… Deduplication in session data
âœ… Edge cases (missing IDs, invalid JSON, no timestamps)

All existing tests (117 total) continue to pass.
Code Changes
Modified Files:

src/data-loader.ts - Added deduplication logic and chronological processing
src/data-loader-deduplication.test.ts - New comprehensive test suite

Key Functions Added:
// Create unique identifier for deduplication
createUniqueHash(data: UsageData): string | null

// Extract earliest timestamp from JSONL file
getEarliestTimestamp(filePath: string): Promise<Date | null>

// Sort files chronologically
sortFilesByTimestamp(files: string[]): Promise<string[]>
Impact

Accurate Costs: Users will see correct token counts and costs
Proper Attribution: Usage is attributed to the original date, not branch date
No Data Loss: Only true duplicates are removed
Performance: Minimal overhead from sorting files before processing

Verification
Before this fix:

Branched conversations would show inflated costs
Same usage could appear on multiple dates

After this fix:

Each unique API call is counted exactly once
Usage appears only on the original date
Branched conversations no longer inflate costs

Breaking Changes
None. This change is backward compatible and transparent to users.
Future Considerations
This implementation uses a simple concatenation for the hash (messageId:requestId). If needed, this could be upgraded to use a proper hashing algorithm, though the current approach is sufficient for the use case.

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Improved data loading by processing usage data files in chronological order.
Added deduplication to ensure duplicate messages are filtered out during data loading.


Bug Fixes

Prevented duplicate entries from affecting usage and session statistics.


Tests

Added comprehensive tests to verify deduplication and chronological processing of data files.

title: feat!: specify claude dir with `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR` and remove `-p`/`--path` option
bodyText:
Summary

Remove -p short option: Removed the `-p` short option since Claude data directory can now be configured via `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR` environment variable
Remove --path option entirely: Completely removed the `--path` CLI option to simplify the interface and encourage environment variable usage
Update all commands: Modified daily, monthly, session, and mcp commands to use `getDefaultClaudePath()` directly
Update documentation: Updated README to remove all references to `--path` option and clarify environment variable usage

Changes Made
CLI Interface Changes

Removed `path` argument from `shared-args.internal.ts`
Updated all command files to import and use `getDefaultClaudePath()` directly
No longer accepts `--path` or `-p` options - users must use `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR` environment variable

Documentation Updates

Removed `--path` option from CLI options documentation in README
Updated usage examples to remove `--path` references
Clarified that only `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR` environment variable is supported for custom paths

Test Coverage

All existing tests continue to pass
No test changes needed as the functionality remains the same, just configured differently

Breaking Change Notice
âš ï¸ This is a breaking change: The `--path` and `-p` options are no longer available. Users who were using these options should set the `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR` environment variable instead:
```bash
Before (no longer works):
ccusage daily --path /custom/path
After:
export CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR="/custom/path"
ccusage daily
```
Test Plan

 All existing tests pass
 Linting passes
 CLI works with default path (~/.claude)
 CLI works with CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR environment variable
 All commands (daily, monthly, session, mcp) use environment variable correctly
 Documentation updated to reflect changes


Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

The tool now supports specifying the Claude data directory via the CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR environment variable.


Bug Fixes

Improved validation to ensure the specified data directory exists and is valid.


Documentation

Updated instructions to reflect the use of the CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR environment variable and removed references to the deprecated --path option.


Chores

Added a new dependency to support directory validation.


Tests

Added comprehensive tests for environment variable handling and directory validation.

title: feat: add offline mode support for cost calculations
bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds comprehensive offline mode support to enable cost calculations without network connectivity to the LiteLLM API. The implementation uses a build-time macro system to pre-fetch and embed pricing data directly into the binary.
Key Features

Build-time Pricing Cache: Automatically fetches and caches all Claude model pricing data during build
Offline CLI Flag: Adds --offline flag support to all commands (daily, monthly, session)
Graceful Degradation: Falls back to offline mode when network is unavailable
Full Test Coverage: Comprehensive tests for both online and offline modes

Technical Implementation

Macro System: Uses unplugin-macro to fetch LiteLLM pricing data at build time
Dual Mode Support: PricingFetcher supports both online (API) and offline (cached) modes
Consistent Interface: No changes to existing CLI usage patterns
Error Handling: Robust fallback behavior when offline data is unavailable

Usage
# Use offline mode (no network required)
ccusage daily --offline
ccusage monthly --offline
ccusage session --offline

# Online mode (default, requires network)
ccusage daily
ccusage monthly
ccusage session
Test Coverage

Online/offline mode consistency validation
Pre-fetched pricing data verification
End-to-end CLI integration tests
Error handling for edge cases

This change maintains full backward compatibility while adding the flexibility to work without network connectivity.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added an offline mode option to the CLI, allowing users to use cached data instead of fetching from the API.
Offline mode is now available for daily, monthly, and session usage commands.
Pricing data for Claude models can now be prefetched and used in offline mode.



Bug Fixes

Updated model naming conventions in cost calculation and pricing retrieval tests.



Tests

Added tests to verify offline mode functionality and ensure cost calculation works when using cached data.



Chores

Introduced new dependencies and updated build configuration for macro support.

title: feat: add 5-hour blocks report command
bodyText:
Summary
This PR implements a new blocks command to analyze Claude Code usage in 5-hour billing windows as requested in #23.
Features

5-Hour Block Tracking: Groups usage into Claude's 5-hour session windows that start with first message
Active Block Monitoring: Shows time elapsed/remaining and burn rate for current sessions
Token Limit Support: Set limits with -t <number> or use -t max to automatically use highest previous block
Usage Projections: Projects total usage if current burn rate continues for the full 5 hours
Recent Filter: --recent flag shows only last 3 days of blocks
Detailed Active View: --active flag shows detailed view of current active block

Implementation Details

Core logic in src/utils/five-hour-blocks.ts handles block detection and calculations
New CLI command in src/commands/blocks.ts with table and JSON output formats
Integrated with existing data loader infrastructure
Added comprehensive documentation to README

title: fix: implement responsive table layout for narrow terminals
bodyText:
Summary


Fixes issue #81: Narrow terminal widths disrupt table layout
Implements ResponsiveTable utility class that wraps cli-table3 with dynamic column width calculation
Uses string-width library for accurate character width measurement (handles ANSI, emoji, full-width characters)
Provides conditional date formatting that uses compact format (year with line break) when space is constrained
Replaces manual separator rows with empty rows for cleaner visual separation before totals

Key Features

Dynamic Width Calculation: Automatically adjusts column widths based on terminal width and content
Content-First Approach: Uses actual content width to determine optimal column sizing
Intelligent Resizing: Applies minimum width constraints while scaling down when needed
Conditional Date Formatting: Shows full date when space available, compact format when constrained
String-Width Integration: Proper width calculation for colored text, emojis, and multi-byte characters
Graceful Separator Handling: Skips separator rows to let cli-table3 handle borders automatically

Test Plan

 Test with various terminal widths (narrow: 80 cols, wide: 120+ cols)
 Verify no content truncation when sufficient width available
 Confirm conditional date formatting works correctly
 Test with colored output and special characters
 Run full test suite to ensure no regressions
 Verify linting and type checking passes

title: feat: add 5-hour session window tracking (closes #23)
bodyText:
Summary

Implements 5-hour session window tracking to help users monitor their Claude Max plan usage
Adds --windows flag to show detailed session window statistics
Adds --session-limit flag (default: 50) to calculate remaining sessions

Key Changes
New Features

Window Calculation: Added utilities to calculate 5-hour UTC-based session windows (00:00, 05:00, 10:00, 15:00, 20:00)
Enhanced Session Command:

--windows flag displays 5-hour session window statistics
--session-limit flag sets plan limit for utilization tracking (default: 50)


Calendar Month Tracking: Sessions are counted per calendar month (UTC) with clear documentation about billing cycle differences

Implementation Details

Added window calculation utilities in utils.internal.ts
Added window aggregation functions in data-loader.ts
Enhanced session command with new display mode for window statistics
Added comprehensive tests for window calculations and aggregation
Updated documentation in README.md and CLAUDE.md

User Experience

Shows session utilization percentage with color coding (green/yellow/red)
Displays warnings when approaching session limits
Provides clear indication when session limit is reached
Shows top 10 most recent windows with usage details

Test Plan

 All existing tests pass
 Added unit tests for window calculation utilities
 Added integration tests for window aggregation
 Manual testing with various date ranges and session limits
 Verified calendar month counting behavior
 Tested JSON output format

Example Usage
# Show 5-hour session windows with default limit (50)
ccusage session --windows

# Show windows with custom session limit
ccusage session --windows --session-limit 30

# JSON output for programmatic use
ccusage session --windows --json
Notes

Sessions are counted per calendar month in UTC timezone
Actual billing cycles may differ from calendar months
The 50 session default is based on Claude Max plan documentation

Fixes #23
ğŸ¤– Generated with Claude Code

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Introduced 5-hour session window tracking for usage statistics, allowing users to view and analyze usage grouped by UTC-based 5-hour intervals.
Added options to specify session limits and receive warnings when approaching or exceeding plan limits.


Documentation

Updated user guides and feature descriptions to explain the new 5-hour window tracking, session limit warnings, and related command-line options.
Expanded usage examples and detailed option explanations for enhanced clarity.


Tests

Added comprehensive tests for window-based aggregation, monthly summaries, and new utility functions.


Style

Improved formatting for duration outputs and window statistics displays.

Release Notes

lint-staged/lint-staged (lint-staged)
v16.1.1
Compare Source
Patch Changes


#â€‹1565 3686977 Thanks @â€‹iiroj! - Lint-staged now explicitly warns about potential data loss when using --no-stash.


#â€‹1571 02299a9 Thanks @â€‹iiroj! - Function tasks (introduced in v16.0.0) only received the staged files matching the conpmnfigured glob, instead of all staged files.


#â€‹1563 bc61c74 Thanks @â€‹iiroj! - This version fixes incorrect behavior where unstaged changes were committed when using the --no-stash option. This happened because --no-stash implied --no-hide-partially-staged, meaning unstaged changes to files which also had other staged changes were added to the commit by lint-staged; this is no longer the case.
The previous (incorrect) behavior can still be achieved by using both options --no-stash --no-hide-partially-staged at the same time.

title: refactor: rename five-hour terminology to session terminology
bodyText:
Summary
This PR refactors the codebase to use session terminology instead of five-hour terminology, aligning with Claude Code official billing session concept. Based on Anthropic documentation, Claude Code uses 5-hour sessions for billing, so the code should reflect this semantic meaning rather than just describing the duration.
Changes Made

Constants: FIVE_HOURS_MS â†’ SESSION_DURATION_MS
Types: FiveHourBlock â†’ SessionBlock
Functions: identifyFiveHourBlocks â†’ identifySessionBlocks, loadFiveHourBlockData â†’ loadSessionBlockData
Files: five-hour-blocks.internal.ts â†’ session-blocks.internal.ts
User-facing text: Updated command descriptions, error messages, and UI labels
Tests: Updated all test files to use new terminology

Why This Change?
After researching Claude Code billing documentation, I found that the 5-hour period represents Claude official session billing cycle. Users start a session with their first message, and it lasts for 5 hours. The term session is more semantically accurate than five-hour blocks and aligns with Anthropic official terminology.
Impact

âœ… All tests pass
âœ… TypeScript compilation successful
âœ… ESLint formatting applied
âœ… No breaking changes to functionality
âœ… Only terminology and naming updated
âœ… Documentation reflects accurate Claude Code billing concepts

Test Plan

 Run bun test - all 155 tests pass
 Run bun typecheck - no TypeScript errors
 Run bun run format - code properly formatted
 Verify functionality unchanged - session block logic works identically
 Check user-facing text updated consistently across CLI and MCP server


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Updated all terminology and functionality from "five-hour blocks" to "session blocks" across the app, including commands, descriptions, logs, and data structures.
Renamed relevant constants, types, and functions to reflect the new "session block" terminology.


Tests

Updated all tests to use "session blocks" instead of "five-hour blocks," ensuring scenarios and expectations remain consistent.

title: style: standardize schema naming conventions
bodyText:
Summary

Standardize Valibot schema variable names to follow camelCase convention (variables start with lowercase)
Rename all schema variables from PascalCase to camelCase while keeping type names unchanged
Add naming conventions documentation to CLAUDE.md
Fix test command documentation in CLAUDE.md

Changes Made
Schema Renames (6 commits, one per schema):


UsageDataSchema â†’ usageDataSchema

Main schema for Claude usage data from JSONL files
Updated in data-loader.ts and debug.ts



ModelBreakdownSchema â†’ modelBreakdownSchema

Schema for model-specific usage breakdown data
Updated all array references in other schemas



DailyUsageSchema â†’ dailyUsageSchema

Schema for daily usage aggregation data



SessionUsageSchema â†’ sessionUsageSchema

Schema for session-based usage aggregation data



MonthlyUsageSchema â†’ monthlyUsageSchema

Schema for monthly usage aggregation data



ModelPricingSchema â†’ modelPricingSchema

Schema for model pricing information from LiteLLM
Updated in types.internal.ts, macro.internal.ts, and pricing-fetcher.ts



Documentation Updates:

Added naming conventions to CLAUDE.md:

Variables: camelCase (e.g., usageDataSchema, modelBreakdownSchema)
Types: PascalCase (e.g., UsageData, ModelBreakdown)
Constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE (e.g., DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CODE_PATH)


Fixed test command documentation to use "bun run test"

Test Results
âœ… All 164 tests pass
âœ… TypeScript compilation successful
âœ… ESLint formatting applied
Naming Convention Rationale
This change follows standard JavaScript/TypeScript conventions:

Variables (including schema definitions): start with lowercase letter
Types/Interfaces: start with uppercase letter
Constants: can use UPPER_SNAKE_CASE

The schemas are Valibot schema objects assigned to const variables, so they should follow variable naming conventions (camelCase), while the inferred types from these schemas correctly follow type naming conventions (PascalCase).

title: refactor: migrate to zod and official MCP SDK with HTTP transport support
bodyText:
Summary
This PR completes a major dependency migration and architecture modernization with significant bundle size improvements:
â€¢ Validation Library Migration: Replace valibot with zod for all schema validation, improving type safety and ecosystem compatibility
â€¢ MCP SDK Upgrade: Migrate from fastmcp to the official @modelcontextprotocol/sdk for better standards compliance
â€¢ HTTP Transport Support: Add HTTP transport capability to the MCP server using Hono framework, enabling web-based integrations
â€¢ Bundle Size Optimization: Reduced total bundle size by 47% (2184.77 kB â†’ 1161.68 kB)
â€¢ Code Quality Improvements: Enhanced documentation, simplified validation logic, and modernized null handling
Performance Improvements
Bundle Size Reduction:

Before: â„¹ 34 files, total: 2184.77 kB
After: â„¹ 23 files, total: 1161.68 kB
Improvement: -1023.09 kB (-47% reduction)

This significant size reduction improves:

Faster installation and startup times
Reduced memory footprint
Better performance on resource-constrained environments

Changes Made
Core Dependencies:

Replaced valibot with zod for schema validation throughout the codebase
Migrated from fastmcp to @modelcontextprotocol/sdk for official MCP protocol support
Added hono and @hono/node-server for HTTP transport functionality

Schema Migration:

Updated all validation schemas in data-loader.ts, types.ts, and command files
Maintained backward compatibility with existing data structures
Improved type inference and runtime validation

MCP Server Enhancements:

Added HTTP transport support alongside existing stdio transport
Implemented flexible transport selection via CLI flags
Enhanced server configuration and error handling

Code Quality Improvements:

Added comprehensive JSDoc documentation to key MCP functions
Removed redundant argument validation in MCP tools (MCP SDK handles validation)
Simplified error handling with explicit fallback messages
Replaced ternary null checks with nullish coalescing operator (??) for cleaner code

Benefits

Better Type Safety: Zod provides superior TypeScript integration and runtime validation
Official MCP Support: Using the official SDK ensures better compatibility and future support
Enhanced Flexibility: HTTP transport enables new integration possibilities
Improved Performance: 47% bundle size reduction improves startup and memory usage
Better Developer Experience: Better error messages, improved documentation, and cleaner code
Reduced Code Complexity: Eliminated redundant validation and simplified conditional logic

AI Review Feedback Addressed
This PR incorporates feedback from multiple AI code reviewers:

CodeRabbit: Added comprehensive JSDoc documentation
Gemini Code Assist: Removed redundant argument validation in MCP server tools
Copilot: Improved error handling with fallback messages and simplified mode conversion
Additional improvements: Modernized null handling with nullish coalescing operator

title: test: improve MCP server test coverage with comprehensive normal and error cases
bodyText:
Summary

Add comprehensive HTTP transport tests with actual MCP protocol requests
Add error handling tests for invalid arguments, dates, and unknown tools
Add edge case tests for empty directories, malformed files, and missing paths
Add concurrent tool call testing for thread safety validation

Background
The MCP server tests were missing coverage for:

Normal HTTP transport operations - Only had basic app creation test
Error handling scenarios - No tests for invalid inputs or error responses
Edge cases - No tests for empty data, malformed files, or concurrent access

Changes Made
1. HTTP Transport Testing

MCP initialize request test - Tests proper SSE response format and JSON-RPC protocol compliance
MCP tool call test - Tests daily tool execution via HTTP with proper response validation
Response format validation - Extracts and validates JSON data from Server-Sent Events responses

2. Error Handling Tests

Invalid arguments test - Tests tool calls with invalid enum values (mode: "invalid_mode")
Invalid date format test - Tests date parameter validation (YYYYMMDD format)
Unknown tool test - Tests error response for non-existent tool names
Uses proper toThrow() exception testing for MCP protocol errors

3. Edge Case Tests

Empty data directory - Tests graceful handling when no usage data exists
Malformed JSONL files - Tests silent skipping of invalid JSON lines
Missing Claude directory - Tests behavior with non-existent data paths
Concurrent tool calls - Tests thread safety with parallel tool execution

Test Results

Before: 11 MCP tests (mainly happy path scenarios)
After: 18 MCP tests (comprehensive coverage)
Total project tests: 182 passing
All tests validated against current Claude 4 models

Technical Details
Protocol Compliance

Tests validate proper JSON-RPC 2.0 format in responses
SSE (Server-Sent Events) format properly parsed and validated
Protocol version and capabilities correctly tested

Error Response Format

MCP SDK throws McpError exceptions for invalid inputs
Tests use expect().rejects.toThrow() for proper exception validation
Error messages include detailed validation information

Edge Case Robustness

Empty data scenarios return valid empty arrays
Malformed files are silently skipped (existing behavior preserved)
Missing directories handled gracefully without crashes
Concurrent access tested for all 4 tools (daily, session, monthly, blocks)

Test Coverage Impact
This PR significantly improves the reliability and robustness testing of the MCP server implementation, ensuring it handles both normal operations and error conditions correctly according to the MCP protocol specification.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Tests

Added extensive new test cases covering HTTP transport and protocol handling, including initialization, tool calls, error scenarios, edge cases, and concurrent requests to ensure robust server behavior.

Key Benefits

Improved readability: uniq() is more explicit about the intent than Set construction
Consistency: Aligns with existing es-toolkit usage patterns in the codebase
Simpler code: Eliminates need for Array.from() conversions
Maintained functionality: All unique collection behavior preserved

What Was Preserved
Set instances used for deduplication checking (via has()/add() methods) were intentionally kept unchanged as they serve a different purpose than unique collection.
Test Plan

 All existing tests pass (182/182)
 TypeScript compilation succeeds
 ESLint formatting applied
 Functionality verified through test suite


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Improved internal logic for extracting unique values by utilizing a standardized utility function, ensuring consistent and reliable uniqueness filtering across various features. No changes to visible features or user-facing functionality.

title: feat: enhance type safety with Zod branded types and performance optimizations
bodyText:
Summary
This comprehensive implementation introduces branded types for enhanced type safety while maintaining performance through strategic optimizations.
ğŸ¯ Key Features
Branded Types Implementation

Core Identifiers: ModelName, SessionId, ProjectPath, Version for compile-time safety
Date Types: DailyDate, ActivityDate, MonthlyDate, ISOTimestamp for temporal data validation
Helper Functions: Type-safe constructors with validation (createModelName, createActivityDate, etc.)
Type Safety: Prevents runtime errors and improves IDE support

Performance Optimizations

Smart Parsing: Use type assertions for already-validated data in hot paths
Loop Optimization: Avoid expensive regex validation in array mapping operations
Balanced Approach: Maintain type safety while optimizing critical performance paths

Backward Compatibility

Legacy Support: Relaxed model name validation for synthetic/unknown models
Data Migration: Seamless compatibility with existing JSONL data formats
Non-breaking: All existing functionality preserved

ğŸ“Š Performance Analysis
Bundle Size Impact

Main Branch: 919.38 kB
Current Branch: 922.96 kB
Difference: +3.58 kB (+0.4%) - minimal overhead for comprehensive type safety

Runtime Performance (hyperfine benchmarks, offline mode)
Daily Command Performance
```bash
Main Branch
Time (mean Â± Ïƒ):     612.7 ms Â± 20.9 ms
Range (min â€¦ max):   590.7 ms â€¦ 684.4 ms
Brand Types Branch
Time (mean Â± Ïƒ):     631.3 ms Â± 7.0 ms
Range (min â€¦ max):   618.5 ms â€¦ 645.3 ms
Result: ~3% slower (18.6ms difference)
```
Session Command Performance
```bash
Main Branch
Time (mean Â± Ïƒ):     606.0 ms Â± 9.8 ms
Range (min â€¦ max):   593.1 ms â€¦ 630.4 ms
Brand Types Branch
Time (mean Â± Ïƒ):     620.7 ms Â± 6.0 ms
Range (min â€¦ max):   608.5 ms â€¦ 630.9 ms
Result: ~2.4% slower (14.7ms difference)
```
Monthly Command Performance
```bash
Main Branch
Time (mean Â± Ïƒ):     607.9 ms Â± 6.4 ms
Range (min â€¦ max):   597.5 ms â€¦ 618.9 ms
Brand Types Branch
Time (mean Â± Ïƒ):     622.9 ms Â± 7.4 ms
Range (min â€¦ max):   611.1 ms â€¦ 637.7 ms
Result: ~2.5% slower (15.0ms difference)
```
Performance Trade-off Analysis

Impact: ~3% performance decrease (~15-20ms average)
User Experience: Imperceptible difference (< 100ms threshold)
Benefits: Significant compile-time safety, better IDE support, runtime error prevention
Conclusion: Excellent trade-off for enhanced development experience

ğŸ”§ Technical Implementation
Before (Performance Issues)
```typescript
// Expensive regex validation in loops
modelsUsed: modelsUsed.map(createModelName),  // Validates each model with regex
versions: Array.from(versionSet).sort().map(createVersion),  // Validates each version
modelName: createModelName(modelName),  // Individual validation calls
```
After (Optimized Approach)
```typescript
// Type assertions for already-validated data
modelsUsed: modelsUsed as ModelName[],  // Direct assertion, no re-validation
versions: Array.from(versionSet).sort() as Version[],  // Direct assertion
modelName: modelName as ModelName,  // Direct assertion in aggregation
```
Safety Guarantees
âœ… Input Validation: All data validated by Zod schemas during initial JSONL parsing
âœ… Type Safety: Branded types prevent identifier mix-ups at compile time
âœ… Runtime Safety: Type assertions only used after validation, not before
âœ… IDE Support: Enhanced autocomplete, refactoring, and error detection
ğŸ“ Key Changes
Core Files Modified

src/types.internal.ts: Comprehensive branded type system with Zod schemas
src/data-loader.ts: Performance-optimized parsing with branded type integration
src/calculate-cost.ts: Updated test data with proper branded type constructors

New Branded Types
```typescript
type ModelName = string & { readonly brand: ModelName };
type SessionId = string & { readonly brand: SessionId };
type ActivityDate = string & { readonly brand: ActivityDate }; // YYYY-MM-DD
type DailyDate = string & { readonly brand: DailyDate };   // YYYY-MM-DD
type Version = string & { readonly brand: Version };       // SemVer format
```
Validation Strategy

Strict Validation: Input parsing from JSONL files
Type Assertions: Internal data transformations and aggregations
Helper Functions: Safe construction with validation when needed

ğŸ§ª Test Plan

 Type Checking: All TypeScript compilation passes without errors
 Unit Tests: All 182 tests pass successfully
 Performance Testing: Comprehensive hyperfine benchmarking across all commands
 Bundle Analysis: Size impact verification (+0.4% acceptable)
 Compatibility Testing: Verified with existing data including synthetic model names
 Offline Testing: All benchmarks run with --offline flag to avoid network interference
 Integration Testing: End-to-end functionality verified

ğŸ’¡ Benefits
Developer Experience

Type Safety: Compile-time validation prevents common string identifier errors
IDE Support: Better autocomplete, navigation, and refactoring capabilities
Debugging: Clear type information makes issues easier to identify and fix
Maintainability: Self-documenting code with explicit type contracts

Runtime Benefits

Error Prevention: Branded types catch identifier mix-ups before they cause issues
Data Integrity: Ensured format consistency across the application
Performance Balance: Optimizations where they matter most (hot paths)

Future-Proofing

Extensibility: Easy to add new branded types for additional domain concepts
Migration Path: Smooth upgrade path for existing data and usage patterns
Type Evolution: Foundation for more advanced type safety features

ğŸ”„ Migration Notes
This change is backward compatible - no user action required:

Existing JSONL data continues to work unchanged
All CLI commands maintain identical behavior
API contracts preserved for programmatic usage
Performance characteristics remain within acceptable bounds


Trade-off Summary: ~3% performance cost for significant type safety improvements - excellent value proposition for a development tool prioritizing reliability and maintainability.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Introduced enhanced validation and type safety for key data fields, including dates, identifiers, and model names.
Added helper functions for safely creating and validating these branded data types.



Refactor

Updated internal data handling to use stricter schemas and branded types, improving consistency and reliability across the application.



Tests

Adjusted test data to conform to the new type-safe schemas and branded types.

title: refactor: consolidate scattered constants into centralized consts.internal.ts
bodyText:
Summary

Consolidate scattered constants from multiple files into a centralized consts.internal.ts
Add comprehensive JSDoc documentation for all constants
Use context-specific naming conventions (e.g., BLOCKS_, DEBUG_, MCP_) for clarity
Replace hardcoded values with named constants throughout the codebase
Maintain single source of truth for configuration values

Changes Made
Constants Consolidated
Time/Duration Constants:

DEFAULT_RECENT_DAYS = 3 - Recent days filtering across commands

UI/Display Constants:

BLOCKS_WARNING_THRESHOLD = 0.8 - Usage warning threshold (80%)
BLOCKS_COMPACT_WIDTH_THRESHOLD = 120 - Terminal width for compact mode
BLOCKS_DEFAULT_TERMINAL_WIDTH = 120 - Fallback terminal width

Threshold/Tolerance Constants:

DEBUG_MATCH_THRESHOLD_PERCENT = 0.1 - Cost matching tolerance for debug validation

File/Path Constants:

DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CODE_PATH = ".claude" - Claude data directory name
CLAUDE_PROJECTS_DIR_NAME = "projects" - Projects directory name
USAGE_DATA_GLOB_PATTERN = "**/*.jsonl" - JSONL file search pattern

Network/System Constants:

MCP_DEFAULT_PORT = 8080 - MCP server default port
USER_HOME_DIR - Centralized home directory access

Files Modified

src/consts.internal.ts - New centralized constants file
src/commands/blocks.ts - Updated to use centralized constants
src/commands/mcp.ts - Updated to use MCP_DEFAULT_PORT
src/data-loader.ts - Updated to use path and file constants
src/debug.ts - Updated to use debug threshold constant
src/session-blocks.internal.ts - Removed duplicate constants

Benefits

Single Source of Truth: All configuration values in one place
Better Maintainability: Easy to update values across the entire codebase
Clear Naming: Context-specific prefixes make usage intent obvious
Documentation: JSDoc explains purpose and usage for each constant
Type Safety: No more magic numbers/strings scattered throughout code

Test Plan

 All existing tests pass (182/182)
 TypeScript compilation succeeds
 ESLint formatting completes without errors
 No functional changes - pure refactoring
 Constants maintain same values as before consolidation


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Centralized configuration values and path definitions by replacing hardcoded constants and strings with shared constants across the application.
Updated descriptions and behaviors to dynamically reflect these centralized values.


Chores

Improved maintainability by consolidating default settings, directory names, file patterns, and thresholds into a single internal module.

title: Add real-time monitoring for active session block
bodyText:
The watch command provides real-time monitoring  within the current active block. It displays a live dashboard showing:

Key Features:

Time countdown bar - Shows remaining time in the current block with color-coded warnings (green/yellow/red)
Cost usage bar - Visualizes spending by model type (Opus/Sonnet/Haiku) with projections
Live statistics - Current tokens and costs with estimated end-of-block totals
Interactive controls - Toggle detailed views with keyboard shortcuts (T/C/P)
Session summary - Shows duration, tokens used, and cost when exiting

Visual Elements:

Progress bars use colored blocks (â– ) to show usage
Models are color-coded: Opus (blue), Sonnet (cyan), Haiku (magenta)

Smart Features:

Automatically adjusts update frequency based on activity (5s to 60s intervals)
Projects total usage based on current burn rate
Warns when approaching time limits
Tracks usage changes during the monitoring session

This tool is perfect for developers who want to keep an eye on their Claude Code usage in real-time, helping them stay within budget and manage their token consumption
effectively.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Introduced a new "watch" CLI command for real-time monitoring of session usage, showing tokens, costs, burn rates, and time remaining with interactive controls.
Added detailed token, cost, and burn rate breakdown tables with color-coded progress bars and projections.
Implemented adaptive refresh intervals and keyboard shortcuts to toggle detailed views and exit monitoring mode.
Added session summary display upon exiting watch mode.



Improvements

Enhanced model name formatting to support legacy formats for clearer usage categorization.

title: feat: Support multiple Claude data directories to handle v1.0.30+ path change
bodyText:
Summary
fixes: #121
This PR adds support for multiple Claude data directories to handle different Claude Code installations and the breaking change where logs moved from ~/.claude to ~/.config/claude.
Key Features
â€¢ Multiple Path Support: Automatically searches both ~/.config/claude/projects/ (new default) and ~/.claude/projects/ (old default)
â€¢ Environment Variable: Set CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR to specify custom path(s) - supports comma-separated multiple paths
â€¢ Data Aggregation: Usage data from all valid directories is automatically combined
â€¢ Backward Compatibility: Existing configurations continue to work without changes
Implementation Highlights
â€¢ Core Functionality: New getClaudePaths() function with path normalization and duplicate removal
â€¢ Environment Support: CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR accepts single or comma-separated multiple paths
â€¢ Robust Testing: Comprehensive test coverage with CI improvements for multiple path scenarios
â€¢ Code Quality: Refactored imports to use .ts extensions, replaced custom utilities with @antfu/utils
Commit Organization
Each commit represents a logical grouping:

Constants: Core constants for multiple path support
Core Implementation: getClaudePaths function and data loading updates
Code Quality: Dependency updates and import standardization
Testing Infrastructure: CI improvements for multiple path testing
Documentation: Updated README and CLAUDE.md with usage examples

Breaking Changes
None - this is fully backward compatible. Existing users will see no changes in behavior.
Migration Path
â€¢ No Action Required: Existing ~/.claude installations continue working
â€¢ Optional: Set CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR environment variable for custom paths
â€¢ Future-Proof: New ~/.config/claude installations are automatically detected
Test Plan

 Existing functionality works unchanged
 Multiple paths are correctly detected and combined
 Environment variable support works for single and multiple paths
 Path normalization prevents duplicates
 CI tests pass with both directory structures
 Backward compatibility maintained for deprecated functions


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for detecting and aggregating Claude Code usage data from multiple directories, including both new and legacy default locations.
Users can now specify custom data directories using the CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR environment variable, supporting multiple comma-separated paths.



Documentation

Updated documentation and README to explain multi-directory support and new configuration options.



Chores

Enhanced CI workflow to create both legacy and new default data directories for testing.
Added a new development dependency for utilities.

title: feat: Add XDG Base Directory Specification support for config paths
bodyText:
Summary

Replace hardcoded ~/.config paths with XDG-compliant configuration directory resolution
Add xdg-basedir dependency for proper XDG Base Directory Specification support
Maintain backward compatibility with existing ~/.claude directory structure
Update all path resolution logic across data-loader, debug, and constants modules

Changes Made
Dependencies

Added `xdg-basedir` as dev dependency for XDG directory specification compliance

Constants Module (`_consts.ts`)

Import `xdgConfig` from xdg-basedir library
Update `DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CONFIG_PATH` to use `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` when available, fallback to `~/.config/claude`
Add `XDG_CONFIG_DIR` constant for future extensibility
Reorder constant definitions to fix dependency order issues

Data Loader Module (`data-loader.ts`)

Replace hardcoded path construction with XDG-aware constants
Use `DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CONFIG_PATH` directly in `getClaudePaths()` function
Update error messages to show XDG-resolved paths
Maintain full backward compatibility with existing ~/.claude directory

Debug Module (`debug.ts`)

Replace `DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CODE_PATH` with `DEFAULT_CLAUDE_CONFIG_PATH` for default path resolution
Remove unused `USER_HOME_DIR` import
Use XDG-aware path resolution for Claude directory detection

Benefits

Standards Compliance: Follows XDG Base Directory Specification for proper Linux/Unix config directory handling
User Control: Respects `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` environment variable when set by users
Backward Compatibility: Continues to work with existing ~/.claude installations
Cross-Platform: Works consistently across different Unix-like systems
Future-Proof: Provides foundation for other XDG directory types (data, cache, etc.)

Testing

All existing tests pass without modification
XDG path resolution tested in multiple scenarios
Backward compatibility verified with legacy ~/.claude directories
Environment variable handling tested for `CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR` and `XDG_CONFIG_HOME`

Migration Impact
No breaking changes - existing users will see no difference in behavior unless they specifically set `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` environment variable.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Improved configuration directory handling to support XDG config directories, providing better compatibility with various operating systems.



Chores

Added "xdg-basedir" as a development dependency for enhanced config path management.



Refactor

Updated internal logic to use dynamic configuration paths based on the XDG standard, replacing hardcoded paths and centralizing home directory access.

title: feat(blocks): add live monitoring mode with real-time usage dashboard
bodyText:
Add --live flag to blocks command for real-time monitoring
Display session progress, token usage, burn rate, and cost projections
Implement efficient incremental data loading to minimize file I/O
Default to 'max' token limit when not specified in live mode
Support customizable refresh intervals (1-60 seconds)
Add professional box-based terminal UI with proper alignment
Extract live monitoring logic to dedicated blocks-live.ts module
Add LiveMonitor class for efficient file change tracking

The live mode provides a dashboard that updates every few seconds showing:

Current session progress with time remaining
Token usage with burn rate indicators (normal/moderate/high)
Cost projections to help users stay within limits
Model information for the active session

Example usage:
bun run start blocks --live bun run start blocks --live --token-limit 60000 bun run start blocks --live --refresh-interval 5

title: fix: add offline flag support to blocks command
bodyText:
Description
This PR fixes the --offline flag not working for the blocks command.
Problem
The --offline flag works correctly for commands like monthly but does not work for the blocks command. When running ccusage blocks --offline, the command still attempts to fetch pricing data from the API instead of using cached data.
Root Cause
The issue occurs in two places:

In src/commands/blocks.ts, the offline parameter was not being passed to loadSessionBlockData()
In src/data-loader.ts, the loadSessionBlockData() function was not passing the offline parameter to the PricingFetcher constructor

Solution

Added offline: ctx.values.offline to the options object passed to loadSessionBlockData() in src/commands/blocks.ts
Changed new PricingFetcher() to new PricingFetcher(options?.offline) in src/data-loader.ts

This matches the implementation in other commands like monthly which correctly handle the offline flag.
Testing
After this fix:

ccusage blocks --offline now correctly uses cached pricing data
ccusage blocks --no-offline (or without the flag) fetches fresh pricing data
Behavior is now consistent with other commands

Fixes #127
ğŸ¤– Generated with Claude Code
Co-Authored-By: Claude noreply@anthropic.com

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Improved support for offline mode during session block data loading, enabling better handling of pricing data when offline functionality is active.

title: fix: use getClaudePaths for multi-directory support
bodyText:
Remove claudePath parameter from data loading functions in all commands
This allows the data loader to check multiple Claude directories automatically
Supports both ~/.config/claude and ~/.claude paths
Fixes 'No Claude usage data found' error when data exists in alternate locations


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Simplified data loading and mismatch detection by removing explicit usage of the default Claude path across several commands. The system now defaults to implicit or no path, streamlining internal processes. No changes to user-facing features or command usage.

title: Isolated Flag and Additional Header Information with Claude Config Directory being used
bodyText:
Overview: Added a new --isolated flag to all commands that restricts usage analysis to only the
CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR environment variable, enabling targeted analysis of specific Claude installations.
Key Changes:
â€¢ Added --isolated flag - New -i, --isolated option available on all four main commands (daily, monthly,
session, blocks) to use only a specific Claude config directory
â€¢ Enhanced configuration display - Added header information showing which Claude config directory is being used
and the specific paths being read from
â€¢ Isolated mode headers - Commands display "Isolated" prefix in titles when using the flag (e.g., "Isolated
Daily", "Isolated Sessions")
â€¢ JSON output support - Isolated mode includes isolatedPaths field in JSON output for programmatic use
â€¢ Robust error handling - Clear error messages when CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is not set or points to invalid
directories
Use Cases:

Analyze usage from a specific Claude Code instance
Separate personal vs work usage analysis
Troubleshoot specific installations
Ensure data comes from only one source

Usage Examples:
export CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR="/path/to/specific/claude"
ccusage daily --isolated
ccusage blocks -i
This addition provides users with precise control over which Claude configuration to analyze while maintaining
full backward compatibility.

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Added new commands for detailed usage reporting from isolated Claude configuration directories, including daily and session billing block reports with advanced filtering, projections, and token limit monitoring.
Introduced the ability to display which configuration directories are being used in various usage reports.


Improvements

Enhanced reporting commands to provide clearer feedback about the source of configuration data.
Improved support for handling multiple configuration paths and isolated environments across commands.


Bug Fixes

Improved error handling and user feedback when configuration directories are missing or invalid.

Session block start times are now consistently aligned to the beginning of the hour, improving accuracy in session grouping.


Tests

title: feat: add proxy support for network-restricted environments
bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds automatic proxy support to resolve network connectivity issues in environments with restricted access to GitHub (such as mainland China).
Changes Made

Automatic proxy detection: Checks for http_proxy, https_proxy, HTTP_PROXY, and HTTPS_PROXY environment variables
Undici ProxyAgent integration: Uses undici's ProxyAgent for fetch requests when proxy is configured
Build-time support: Extends proxy support to macro execution during build process
Debug logging: Adds informative logging when proxy is detected and used

Files Modified

src/pricing-fetcher.ts: Added proxy detection and ProxyAgent usage in ensurePricingLoaded()
src/_macro.ts: Added proxy support for build-time pricing data fetching

Problem Solved
Fixes the issue where npx ccusage@latest fails in network-restricted environments due to inability to fetch pricing data from GitHub raw content. Users previously had to use --offline mode or clone the repository locally to work around this limitation.
Testing
Tested successfully with:

Local development environment with proxy
Published test package ccusage-test@15.1.0 via npx with proxy configuration
Verified proxy detection and usage logging

Usage
No changes required for existing users. The tool will automatically detect and use proxy settings from environment variables when available.
Example:
export https_proxy=http://127.0.0.1:8888
npx ccusage@latest daily  # Now works in restricted environments
ğŸ¤– Generated with Claude Code
Co-Authored-By: Claude noreply@anthropic.com

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for routing pricing data fetch requests through a proxy if proxy environment variables are configured.



Chores

Improved logging to indicate when a proxy is being used for fetch operations.

bodyText:
This ccusage project as inspired lots of people.
Who doesn't love to see how much value they are getting from a subscription.
So I decided to build a native app to visualise some of the data from ccusage,
Because why not, and it kinda turned out really well so i've published it.
https://github.com/EthanBarlo/ccusage-app
Its very fresh and its only been tested so far on Macos.
So feel free to test it out, and see if it works on other platforms.
Obviously open to contributions,
And ideas for what charts would be useful.
And theres definitely room for improvement, but here is the first initial version.
Dashboard

Projects

Sessions

It does also show a countdown and some stats on the currently active session as well.
But I don't have one started right now to screenshot.

Settings
To configure the billling date / subscription reset.


Summary by CodeRabbit
