title: fix: reduce screen flickering in live monitoring using alternate screen buffer
bodyText:
Summary

Implement alternate screen buffer for live monitoring display to eliminate screen flickering
Remove redundant screen clearing operations in the render loop
Add proper cleanup to restore terminal state on exit

Problem
The current implementation clears the entire screen on every refresh cycle, which causes visible flickering on slower terminals or when refresh rates are high. This creates a poor user experience, especially during extended monitoring sessions.
Solution
This PR introduces alternate screen buffer support (similar to how `vim` or `less` work):

Uses ANSI escape sequences to switch to an alternate screen buffer when monitoring starts
The alternate buffer handles screen updates more efficiently, reducing flicker
Automatically restores the original terminal content when monitoring ends

Changes


TerminalManager enhancements:

Added `enterAlternateScreen()` method to switch to alternate buffer
Added `exitAlternateScreen()` method to restore original screen
Updated `cleanup()` to properly exit alternate screen



Live monitoring improvements:

Enter alternate screen when starting live monitoring
Removed redundant `clearScreen()` call before each render
The alternate buffer handles clearing automatically



Test Plan

 Tested live monitoring with `bun run start blocks --active`
 Verified no flickering on terminal refresh
 Confirmed terminal properly restores on exit (Ctrl+C)
 Ensured all tests pass (`bun run test`)
 Code formatting and linting pass (`bun run format` and ESLint)
 TypeScript checks pass (`bun typecheck`)

Impact
This change significantly improves the user experience for live monitoring features without affecting any other functionality. The alternate screen buffer is a standard terminal feature supported by all modern terminal emulators.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Introduced support for alternate screen buffer mode in the terminal, enhancing the live display experience with reduced flicker and improved screen management.



Improvements

Terminal now automatically exits alternate screen buffer mode during cleanup, ensuring a smoother return to the original terminal state after live monitoring sessions.

title: Improve `blocks --live` rendering
bodyText:
I noticed when I wasn't focused on the terminal in Ghostty, the live terminal had some bad flickering. The cursor was also still being shown.

This addresses that by using the alternate screen provided by terminal emulators.
Also collects all writes and flushes them in a single operation.
Enables DEC mode 2026 for atomic screen updates.
It also makes sure the cursor is hidden.
It also caps the refresh rate at 60fps to preserve CPU

NOTE: only tested in Ghostty
NOTE: couldn't figure out how to auto-format, eslint wasn't doing it, so I used prettier which may have caused too many changes

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Improved terminal output handling with synchronized output mode to reduce flicker and screen tearing during live updates.
Added support for alternate screen buffer, enhancing the live monitoring display experience.
Introduced frame rate limiting to optimize rendering frequency and improve performance.



Bug Fixes

Enhanced error handling to ensure terminal state is properly restored and messages are displayed correctly.



Style

Refined terminal UI formatting for clearer, smoother, and more consistent rendering during live monitoring.

title: refactor: extract live monitoring rendering logic for better code organization
bodyText:
Summary
This PR refactors the live monitoring functionality to improve code organization by separating concerns between the CLI layer and business logic.
Changes Made
ğŸ—ï¸ Code Structure Improvements

Extract rendering logic: Move all display logic from `commands/_blocks.live.ts` to new `src/_live-rendering.ts` module
Thin CLI layer: Reduce command file from ~520 lines to ~95 lines, keeping only process lifecycle management
Better separation of concerns: Commands now act as orchestration layers, business logic is isolated and testable

ğŸ”§ Code Quality Improvements

Fix terminal buffer management: Ensure buffer is always cleared after flush to prevent duplicate content
Replace hardcoded ANSI sequences: Add named constants for line wrap control and color reset
Improve comment clarity: Replace informal language with precise technical descriptions

ğŸ“ Comment Improvements

Update technical comments to be more specific and educational
Add frame rate limiting explanations (60fps, flicker prevention)
Document DEC synchronized output mode with double-buffering concepts
Clarify terminal buffering and alternate screen functionality

ğŸ§ª Testing

Add comprehensive in-source tests for all extracted functions
Frame rate limiting tests with AbortSignal handling
Display formatting helper function tests
Delay and abort signal integration tests

ğŸ“ File Changes

`src/_live-rendering.ts` (NEW): 483 lines of extracted rendering logic with tests
`src/commands/_blocks.live.ts`: Simplified to 95 lines (was 520+ lines)
`src/_consts.ts`: Improved frame rate limiting comment
`src/_terminal-utils.ts`: Enhanced technical comments, fixed buffer management, added ANSI constants

Benefits

Better maintainability: Logic is separated from CLI concerns
Improved testability: Rendering functions are now independently testable
Reusable components: Display logic can be reused by other parts of the system
Cleaner architecture: Commands focus on process management, modules handle business logic
More robust terminal handling: Fixed buffer clearing and standardized ANSI sequences

Test Results
All 212 tests pass, including 6 new tests for the extracted functionality.
Behavior
âš ï¸ No functional changes - the live monitoring behavior remains identical. This is purely a structural refactoring with code quality improvements.
Related
Addresses the file structure concerns noted in the codebase where command files were becoming too large and mixing concerns. Also addresses PR review feedback for code quality improvements.

title: fix: change OGP image from SVG to PNG for better social media compatibility
bodyText:
Summary

Changed OGP image format from SVG to PNG in VitePress config
This ensures the logo displays correctly on social media platforms

Problem
Many social platforms (Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn) do not support SVG format for Open Graph Protocol previews, causing the logo to not display properly when sharing links.
Solution
Updated the og:image meta tag to use logo.png instead of logo.svg. The PNG format is universally supported by all major social media platforms.
Test plan

 Deploy changes to production
 Test URL preview on Twitter Card Validator
 Test URL preview on Facebook Sharing Debugger
 Test URL preview on LinkedIn Post Inspector
 Verify logo displays correctly in all platforms


Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Updated the Open Graph image for improved link previews by switching from an SVG to a PNG file.

title: feat: add project filtering and grouping to daily command
bodyText:
Summary
Adds project filtering and grouping support to the daily command for tracking Claude Code usage across multiple parallel sessions.
â€¢ Project grouping: New --instances flag displays daily usage breakdown by project
â€¢ Project filtering: New --project flag filters daily results to specific projects
â€¢ Smart aliases: Configure custom project names via CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES env var
â€¢ Enhanced JSON output: Project-grouped data structure for daily reports
â€¢ Improved path parsing: Better extraction of meaningful project names from directory structures
Implementation focuses specifically on the daily command with comprehensive project name handling.
Implementation Details

New _project-names.ts module with intelligent project name parsing and alias support
Enhanced daily data loader with project-aware filtering and grouping
Extended daily command interface with --instances and --project flags
Comprehensive test coverage for project name formatting edge cases
Backward compatible - existing daily command usage patterns unchanged

Usage Examples
# Show daily usage by project
ccusage daily --instances

# Filter daily report to specific project 
ccusage daily --project ccusage

# Custom project aliases for daily reports
export CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES="long-project-name=Short Name"
ccusage daily --instances --json
Closes #137
ğŸ¤– Generated with Claude Code

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added the ability to group and filter usage data by project using new command-line options (--instances, --project) in daily reports.
Introduced support for custom project name aliases via the CCUSAGE_PROJECT_ALIASES environment variable for clearer reporting.
Enhanced JSON and table outputs to display usage breakdowns per project, with improved formatting for project names.



Documentation

Updated user guides and CLI documentation to explain project grouping, filtering, aliasing, and new output formats.
Added detailed examples and usage scenarios for project-level reporting and JSON analysis.



Style

Minor formatting and comment improvements in code for clarity.

title: feat: add currency conversion support with --currency option
bodyText:
Hi! I really love ccusage's minimalist design philosophy, so I'm a bit hesitant to propose this
feature addition.
My personal use case: I wanted to quickly see my Claude costs in JPY without leaving the terminal or
doing manual conversion. So I implemented currency conversion as an optional feature.
Design considerations:

Non-breaking: Defaults to USD, existing behavior unchanged
Opt-in only: Requires explicit --currency  flag
Self-contained: New functionality in separate modules
Daily rate limits: Uses free exchange rate API (open.er-api.com) with 1 request/day limit, cached
locally

Example usage:
ccusage daily --currency JPY  # Â¥4,881 instead of $33.35
ccusage monthly --currency EUR # â‚¬1,520 instead of $1,755
Implementation scope: This adds comprehensive currency support (25+ currencies with proper
formatting) through two new modules for exchange rate fetching and currency conversion, plus minimal
changes to existing commands to integrate the --currency option.
I understand if this feels too heavy for your core mission.
What do you think?

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for displaying costs in multiple currencies, not just USD.
Introduced a command-line option to select the desired currency for cost reports.
Daily usage reports now convert and display costs in the selected currency, with appropriate symbols and formatting.
Currency conversion uses up-to-date exchange rates and supports a wide range of international currencies.
Added currency validation to ensure selected currencies are supported.



Bug Fixes

Improved handling and formatting for unknown or unsupported currencies.



Tests

Expanded unit tests to cover currency formatting, conversion accuracy, validation, and error handling.

title: fix: Include cache tokens in live usage token count calculations
bodyText:
Summary

Fixes live usage monitor and blocks command to include all four token types (input, output, cache_creation_input, cache_read_input)
Adds getTotalTokens() helper function to correctly sum all token types
Updates burn rate and projection calculations to include cache tokens

Test plan

 Build the project with bun run build
 Run ./dist/index.js blocks --live to see live monitoring with accurate token counts
 Verify cache tokens are included in the total (should show values >9M tokens if cache tokens are present)
 Run unit tests with bun run test to verify calculations include cache tokens

Fixes #179

Summary by CodeRabbit

Improvements

Enhanced the accuracy of total token count displayed in live rendering and token usage reports.
Improved alignment of session progress, usage, projection bars, and model information for better visual consistency.
Centralized token counting logic for consistent and reliable token usage calculations across the app.

title: fix: handle file read errors gracefully in live monitor
bodyText:
When Claude Code's cleanupPeriodDays option triggers automatic deletion of old usage logs, ccusage blocks --live crashes with ENOENT errors. This fix adds error handling to silently skip files that cannot be read, allowing live monitoring to continue uninterrupted.


Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Improved error handling to ensure the application continues processing files even if some files are unreadable or inaccessible.

title: chore(deps): update node.js to >=20.19.3
bodyText:
This PR contains the following updates:



Package
Type
Update
Change




node (source)
engines
minor
>=20.0.0 -> >=20.19.3




WarningSome dependencies could not be looked up. Check the warning logs for more information.


Release Notes

nodejs/node (node)
v20.19.3
Compare Source
v20.19.2
Compare Source
v20.19.1
Compare Source
v20.19.0: 2025-03-13, Version 20.19.0 'Iron' (LTS), @â€‹marco-ippolito
Compare Source
Notable Changes
require(esm) is now enabled by default
Support for loading native ES modules using require() had been available on v20.x under the command line flag --experimental-require-module, and available by default on v22.x and v23.x. In this release, it is now no longer behind a flag on v20.x.
This feature has been tested on v23.x and v22.x, and we are looking for user feedback from v20.x to make more final tweaks before fully stabilizing it. When the Node.js instance encounters a native ES module in require() somewhere outside node_modules for the first time, it will emit an experimental warning unless require() comes from a path that contains node_modules.  If there happens to be any regressions caused by this feature, users can report it to the Node.js issue tracker. Meanwhile this feature can also be disabled using --no-experimental-require-module as a workaround.
With this feature enabled, Node.js will no longer throw ERR_REQUIRE_ESM if require() is used to load a ES module. It can, however, throw ERR_REQUIRE_ASYNC_MODULE if the ES module being loaded or its dependencies contain top-level await. When the ES module is loaded successfully by require(), the returned object will either be a ES module namespace object similar to what's returned by import(), or what gets exported as "module.exports" in the ES module.
Users can check process.features.require_module to see whether require(esm) is enabled in the current Node.js instance. For packages, the "module-sync" exports condition can be used as a way to detect require(esm) support in the current Node.js instance and allow both require() and import to load the same native ES module. See the documentation for more details about this feature.
Contributed by Joyee Cheung in #â€‹55085
Module syntax detection is now enabled by default
Module syntax detection (the --experimental-detect-module flag) is now
enabled by default. Use --no-experimental-detect-module to disable it if
needed.
Syntax detection attempts to run ambiguous files as CommonJS, and if the module
fails to parse as CommonJS due to ES module syntax, Node.js tries again and runs
the file as an ES module.
Ambiguous files are those with a .js or no extension, where the nearest parent
package.json has no "type" field (either "type": "module" or
"type": "commonjs").
Syntax detection should have no performance impact on CommonJS modules, but it
incurs a slight performance penalty for ES modules; add "type": "module" to
the nearest parent package.json file to eliminate the performance cost.
A use case unlocked by this feature is the ability to use ES module syntax in
extensionless scripts with no nearby package.json.
Thanks to Geoffrey Booth for making this work on #â€‹53619.
Other Notable Changes

[285bb4ee14] - crypto: update root certificates to NSS 3.107 (Node.js GitHub Bot) #â€‹56566
[73b5c16684] - (SEMVER-MINOR) worker: add postMessageToThread (Paolo Insogna) #â€‹53682
[de313b2336] - (SEMVER-MINOR) module: only emit require(esm) warning under --trace-require-module (Joyee Cheung) #â€‹56194
[4fba01911d] - (SEMVER-MINOR) process: add process.features.require_module (Joyee Cheung) #â€‹55241
[df8a045afe] - (SEMVER-MINOR) module: implement the "module-sync" exports condition (Joyee Cheung) #â€‹54648
[f9dc1eaef5] - (SEMVER-MINOR) module: add __esModule to require()'d ESM (Joyee Cheung) #â€‹52166

title: chore(deps): update node.js to v22
bodyText:
This PR contains the following updates:



Package
Type
Update
Change




node (source)
engines
major
>=20.0.0 -> >=22.17.0




WarningSome dependencies could not be looked up. Check the warning logs for more information.


Release Notes

nodejs/node (node)
v22.17.0: 2025-06-24, Version 22.17.0 'Jod' (LTS), @â€‹aduh95
Compare Source
Notable Changes
âš ï¸ Deprecations
Instantiating node:http classes without new
Constructing classes like IncomingMessage or ServerResponse without the new
keyword is now discouraged. This clarifies API expectations and aligns with standard
JavaScript behavior. It may warn or error in future versions.
Contributed by Yagiz Nizipli in #â€‹58518.
options.shell = "" in node:child_process
Using an empty string for shell previously had undefined behavior. This change
encourages explicit choices (e.g., shell: true or a shell path) and avoids
relying on implementation quirks.
Contributed by Antoine du Hamel and Renegade334 #â€‹58564.
HTTP/2 priority signaling
The HTTP/2 prioritization API (e.g., stream.priority) is now deprecated due to
poor real-world support. Applications should avoid using priority hints and expect future removal.
Contributed by Matteo Collina and Antoine du Hamel #â€‹58313.
âœ… Features graduated to stable
assert.partialDeepStrictEqual()
This method compares only a subset of properties in deep object comparisons,
useful for flexible test assertions. Its stabilization means it's now safe for
general use and won't change unexpectedly in future releases.
Contributed by Ruben Bridgewater in #â€‹57370.
Miscellaneous

dirent.parentPath
filehandle.readableWebStream()
fs.glob()
fs.openAsBlob()
node:readline/promises
port.hasRef()
readable.compose()
readable.iterator()

readable.readableDidRead

Duplex.toWeb()

Startup Snapshot API
ERR_INPUT_TYPE_NOT_ALLOWED
ERR_UNKNOWN_FILE_EXTENSION
ERR_UNKNOWN_MODULE_FORMAT
ERR_USE_AFTER_CLOSE

Contributed by James M Snell in
#â€‹57513 and
#â€‹58541.
Semver-minor features
ğŸ”§ fs.FileHandle.readableWebStream gets autoClose option
This gives developers explicit control over whether the file descriptor should
be closed when the stream ends. Helps avoid subtle resource leaks.
Contributed by James M Snell in #â€‹58548.
ğŸ”§ fs.Dir now supports explicit resource management
This improves ergonomics around async iteration of directories. Developers can
now manually control when a directory is closed using .close() or with Symbol.asyncDispose.
Contributed by Antoine du Hamel in #â€‹58206.
ğŸ“Š http2 gains diagnostics channel: http2.server.stream.finish
Adds observability support for when a stream finishes. Useful for logging,
monitoring, and debugging HTTP/2 behavior without patching internals.
Contributed by Darshan Sen in #â€‹58560.
ğŸ” Permissions: implicit allow-fs-read to entrypoint
Node.js permissions model now allows read access to the entry file by default.
It makes running permission-restricted apps smoother while preserving security.

{

title: fix: replace try-catch with @praha/byethrow Result type for functional error handling
bodyText:
Summary
Add @praha/byethrow dependency and replace traditional try-catch blocks with Result.try() for functional error handling across 11 locations in 5 files.
Key Changes

Add @praha/byethrow@^0.3.0 dependency
Convert JSON parsing try-catch to Result.try() patterns
Replace network operation error handling with functional approach
Use Result.isFailure() for better readability
Document error handling guidelines in CLAUDE.md

Files Modified

src/debug.ts - JSON parsing error handling
src/data-loader.ts - Data loading error handling (3 locations)
src/pricing-fetcher.ts - Network operations (2 locations)
src/_live-monitor.ts - Live monitoring (2 locations)
src/commands/_blocks.live.ts - Monitoring loop (1 location)

Benefits

More functional and composable error handling
Better type safety with explicit Success/Failure types
Clearer error handling patterns
All 210 tests pass with no behavioral changes

Test Status
âœ… TypeScript compilation succeeds
âœ… All tests pass (210/210)
âœ… ESLint formatting applied

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for the @praha/byethrow package and related configuration for enhanced error handling.



Refactor

Replaced traditional try-catch blocks with a structured Result pattern for error handling across multiple modules, improving code clarity and reliability.
Updated statistics tracking logic for improved consistency and structure.



Documentation

Added new guidelines on functional error handling using the Result type to the code style notes.



Chores

Updated development dependencies to include @praha/byethrow and @praha/byethrow-mcp.

title: feat: add CSV output support with refactored shared handlers
bodyText:
Function
The --csv option allows csv output. This is an option that works well with other system integration and spreadsheets such as excel.
Caution.
You may choose not to implement this in ccusage because it is the same as this.
npx ccusage --json | jq -r ' 
 ["date", "inputTokens", "outputTokens", "cacheCreationTokens", "cacheReadTokens", "totalTokens", "totalCost ", "modelsUsed"], 
 (.daily[] | [ 
.date, 
.inputTokens, 
.outputTokens, 
.cacheCreationTokens, 
.cacheReadTokens, 
.totalTokens, 
.totalCost, 
 (. modelsUsed | join(";")) 
 ]) 
 | @csv 
'

title: refactor: Improve the error handling of the PricingFetcher class
refactor: Improve the error handling of the PricingFetcher class
bodyText:
Overview
Improved error handling in the PricingFetcher class to implement more robust and consistent error processing. By leveraging the Result type from @praha/byethrow, error propagation and handling have become safer and more predictable.
Key Changes

Introduction of the Result pattern: All asynchronous operations are wrapped in the Result type for explicit error handling
Enhanced type safety: Changed method return types to R.ResultAsync<T, E>
Error propagation: Adopted a functional programming style for error handling using R.pipe()
Other updates: Refactored processes dependent on the PricingFetcher class


Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Enhanced error handling and consistency in pricing and data loading features with a new functional approach.
Improved reliability in cost calculation and model pricing retrieval logic.


Chores

Updated development dependencies to the latest versions for improved stability.

title: docs: emphasize bunx usage and ultra-small bundle size advantage
bodyText:
Summary

Update installation documentation to emphasize using bunx over npx for speed
Highlight that installation is optional due to incredibly small bundle size
Add bundle size as a key differentiating feature

Changes
README.md

Reorder installation methods to put bunx first as recommended option
Add inline bundle size badge to emphasize small size
Add tip about bunx speed advantage
Mark local installation as optional
Add feature bullet about ultra-small bundle size

Documentation Site

Add section explaining why no installation is needed
Include performance comparison table for different runtimes
Highlight bundle size optimization as first key feature
Add tips and info boxes for better user guidance

Context
Based on the creator's tweets about ccusage:

Bundle size is quite small, so installation is not necessary
bunx is recommended over npx for massive speed difference
Deno is also an option for security-conscious users

This PR makes these advantages more visible to users discovering ccusage.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Updated documentation to highlight the ultra-small bundle size of the CLI tool.
Expanded Quick Start and installation instructions with examples for bunx, npx, and deno, recommending bunx for speed.
Added a new section explaining why installation is optional and included a performance comparison of different runtimes.
Clarified and renamed installation sections to emphasize the optional nature of global installation.

title: Add HTTP proxy support for network-restricted environments
bodyText:
Summary
This PR adds transparent HTTP/HTTPS proxy support to ccusage, enabling users in corporate networks or regions with restricted internet access (such as China) to use the tool through proxy servers like Clash Verge or corporate proxies.
Features

Zero external dependencies - Uses only Node.js built-in modules
Automatic proxy detection - Reads from standard environment variables
Authentication support - Username/password proxy authentication
Graceful fallback - Falls back to direct connection if proxy fails
Full compatibility - Complete Fetch API Response object implementation
Comprehensive testing - 12 unit tests covering all scenarios

Implementation
The implementation uses dependency injection with an HttpClient interface, maintaining full backward compatibility. The core components are:

src/http/client.ts - HTTP client interface definitions
src/http/proxy-aware-client.ts - Zero-dependency proxy implementation
src/http/index.ts - Factory functions and exports
Updated src/pricing-fetcher.ts and src/_macro.ts for integration

Usage
Users can configure proxies using standard environment variables:
export HTTP_PROXY=http://127.0.0.1:7897
export HTTPS_PROXY=http://127.0.0.1:7897

# With authentication
export HTTP_PROXY=http://username:password@proxy.company.com:8080

# Then use ccusage normally
ccusage daily
Benefits

Chinese users can now use ccusage through tools like Clash Verge
Corporate users can use ccusage behind company firewalls
Transparent integration - no changes needed to existing workflows
Maintains project philosophy - zero external dependencies, ultra-small bundle

Testing
All tests pass including 12 new proxy-specific tests covering:

Environment variable detection and parsing
Proxy authentication handling
Error scenarios and graceful fallback
Security considerations (credential protection)

The implementation is production-ready and fully backward compatible.

Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Added automatic HTTP/HTTPS proxy support with environment variable detection and authentication.
Requests now gracefully fall back to direct connections on proxy failure, displaying warnings.


Documentation

Added a detailed HTTP Proxy Support section to the configuration guide with usage examples and scenarios.


Refactor

Network requests updated to use a customizable HTTP client for enhanced proxy support and flexibility.

title: fix: improve error handling for cloud sync ENOENT errors
bodyText:
Summary
This PR improves error handling for cloud synchronization scenarios where JSONL files may be temporarily unavailable due to ongoing sync operations.
Changes

Enhanced live monitoring error handling: Added specific detection and handling for ENOENT errors in _blocks.live.ts
User-friendly messaging: Display warning instead of error for sync-related issues with helpful context
Improved logging: Use debug level for temporary file unavailability to reduce log noise
Better error preservation: Maintain original error information for debugging while handling gracefully
Continue monitoring: ENOENT errors now show warning and continue monitoring instead of terminating the program

Problem Solved
Fixes #246 - Users syncing Claude data directories via cloud storage (like Nutstore) would see error messages when files were temporarily unavailable during sync. This fix makes the tool more resilient to such scenarios by continuing to monitor instead of exiting.
Key Improvements

No program termination: ENOENT errors during cloud sync no longer cause the live monitoring to exit
Graceful recovery: Program automatically recovers when sync completes
Better user experience: Clear warning messages with helpful context
Persistent monitoring: Continues checking for data availability during sync operations

Testing
The changes maintain existing functionality while gracefully handling file access errors. Error handling uses the existing Result.try pattern for consistency. Non-sync errors will still properly terminate the program as expected.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Improved error messages and warnings for file synchronization issues, providing clearer feedback when files are temporarily unavailable due to syncing.



Bug Fixes

Enhanced error handling to better distinguish between file sync errors and other issues, ensuring appropriate logging and user notifications.



Style

Updated session time displays in live monitoring to show hours and minutes (e.g., "1h 23m") instead of compact millisecond-based formats for improved readability.

title: feat: improve time precision in live monitoring display
bodyText:
Summary

Improve time precision in ccusage blocks --live from hour-only to minute-level accuracy
Replace prettyMs compact format with explicit Xh Ym format for remaining time display
Add separate remaining time line in compact terminal mode for better visibility

Changes

Modified renderLiveDisplay() to show remaining time as "Xh Ym" instead of prettyMs compact format
Updated renderCompactLiveDisplay() to display remaining time on separate line
Ensures consistent minute-level precision across all time displays in live monitoring

Test plan

 Verify time format changes display correctly in live mode
 Test both full and compact terminal display modes
 Confirm remaining time shows minutes instead of just hours


Summary by CodeRabbit

Improvements

Enhanced error handling and logging for file access issues, providing clearer messages when files are temporarily unavailable due to cloud sync.
Improved user feedback in the terminal when file synchronization issues occur during live monitoring, preventing unnecessary interruptions.
Updated time display in live session views to show elapsed and remaining times in explicit hours and minutes for better clarity.

Minor Changes


#â€‹9535 56dc5c4 Thanks @â€‹penalosa! - In 2023 we announced breakpoint debugging support for Workers, which meant that you could easily debug your Worker code in Wrangler's built-in devtools (accessible via the [d] hotkey) as well as multiple other devtools clients, including VSCode. For most developers, breakpoint debugging via VSCode is the most natural flow, but until now it's required manually configuring a launch.json file, running wrangler dev, and connecting via VSCode's built-in debugger.
Now, using VSCode's built-in JavaScript Debug Terminals, there are just two steps: open a JS debug terminal and run wrangler dev (or vite dev). VSCode will automatically connect to your running Worker (even if you're running multiple Workers at once!) and start a debugging session.

title: feat(mcp): add runtime detection for Bun and Deno HTTP servers
bodyText:
Summary

Added runtime detection to automatically use native server implementations
Uses Bun.serve() when running in Bun environment for better performance
Uses Deno.serve() when running in Deno environment
Falls back to Node.js serve() for other environments

Changes

Added runtime detection logic in MCP HTTP server initialization using switch statement
Added @types/deno to devDependencies for proper type support
Maintains backward compatibility with existing Node.js deployments

Test plan

 Test MCP server runs correctly in Bun environment
 Test MCP server runs correctly in Deno environment
 Test MCP server falls back correctly in Node.js environment
 Verify all existing functionality works as expected

Added support for running the HTTP server in Bun and Deno environments, in addition to Node.js. The server now automatically detects and uses the appropriate runtime.

title: fix(live-monitor): exclude cache tokens from burn rate indicators
bodyText:
Summary

Fixes burn rate indicator display issue introduced in PR #193
Burn rate display shows total tokens (including cache), but HIGH/MODERATE/NORMAL indicators use only input+output tokens to maintain consistent thresholds
Extracts rate indicator logic to testable function with comprehensive boundary value test coverage
Moves burn rate thresholds to _consts.ts for centralized configuration

Changes

Add `tokensPerMinuteForIndicator` field to BurnRate type for separate threshold calculation
Extract `getRateIndicator()` function with switch(true) pattern for better readability
Add `BURN_RATE_THRESHOLDS` constants to _consts.ts
Comprehensive test coverage including all boundary values (499, 500, 501, 1000, 1001)
Update existing burn rate calculation test to verify cache token separation

Test plan

 All existing tests pass
 New rate indicator function has 100% branch coverage
 Burn rate calculation correctly separates cache and non-cache tokens
 Live monitor displays consistent HIGH/MODERATE/NORMAL indicators

Fixes: #267

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added clearer burn rate indicators ("HIGH", "MODERATE", "NORMAL") based on predefined thresholds for tokens used per minute.
Burn rate calculation now distinguishes between total tokens and tokens used specifically for indicator purposes, improving indicator accuracy.



Tests

Introduced comprehensive tests to ensure correct burn rate indicator behavior and calculation logic.

title: feat(i18n): Implement internationalization support
bodyText:
Add Full Internationalization (i18n) Support
Overview
This pull request implements comprehensive internationalization (i18n) support throughout the ccusage CLI tool. All user-facing stringsâ€”including table headers, error messages, and status informationâ€”are now fully translatable. The CLI detects the system locale or accepts a language override via the --lang option.
Technical Details


Locale Detection:

The CLI checks for a --lang CLI argument, then falls back to environment variables (LANG, LC_ALL, LANGUAGE), and defaults to English if none are set.
Supported languages: English (en), French (fr), Spanish (es), German (de), Japanese (ja), Chinese (zh).



Translation Architecture:

All translations are stored in JSON files under locales (e.g., en.json, fr.json, etc.).
The i18n module loads the appropriate translation file at runtime and falls back to English for missing keys.
Parameter interpolation is supported for dynamic values within translation strings.



TypeScript & ESLint Compliance:

All code now uses strict null checks and explicit type annotations.
Unsafe any usage has been eliminated; all object accesses are type-safe.
All conditional checks on possibly-null or undefined values are explicit.
ESLint errors and warnings have been resolved across the codebase.



CLI Integration:

The language can be set via --lang or -l (e.g., ccusage --lang=fr).
All commands and output (including live monitoring, error messages, and help text) are localized.



Validation & Tooling:

Added and improved translation validation scripts to ensure all locale files are complete and consistent.
The validation script checks for missing, extra, or empty keys and placeholder values.



Documentation:

The README and i18n guide have been updated with usage instructions and language examples.
Markdown code blocks in documentation have been adjusted to avoid ESLint parsing errors.



Motivation
This update makes ccusage accessible to a global audience, ensures robust and maintainable code, and provides a scalable foundation for future language additions.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added full internationalization (i18n) support with multilingual CLI output and reports in English, French, Spanish, German, Japanese, and Chinese.
Introduced a --lang option and automatic locale detection for user-facing text.
All command descriptions, error messages, table headers, and reports are now localized.
Currency formatting and live monitoring UI are adapted to the selected language.



Documentation

Updated README with internationalization details and usage examples.
Added a comprehensive Internationalization Guide covering language selection, translation coverage, and troubleshooting.



Chores

Added translation validation scripts and npm tasks to ensure translation completeness and consistency.
Included new translation files for all supported languages.

title: feat(blocks): add cost-based live monitoring with -c/--cost-limit option
bodyText:
Add new cost limit functionality for live monitoring mode:

Add -c/--cost-limit argument supporting numeric values and "max" keyword
Implement cost-based progress bars and projections in live display
Add mutual exclusivity validation between token and cost limits
Support cost burn rate display ($X.XX/hour) instead of tokens/min
Add maxCostFromAll calculation to find highest cost from previous sessions
Update live rendering to show cost-focused displays when cost limit is active
Maintain backward compatibility with existing token-based monitoring

Technical changes:

Add parseCostLimit() function mirroring parseTokenLimit() logic
Extend LiveMonitoringConfig type with costLimit field
Update compact display mode to support cost limits
Add comprehensive test coverage for cost limit scenarios
Create BUILD.md with local installation and development instructions

Breaking changes: None - fully backward compatible

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for cost-based limits and per-model filtering in live usage monitoring, enabling more flexible and precise tracking.
Introduced ranked limit parsing for token and cost limits, including support for "2nd-max", "3rd-max", etc.
Added model filtering options to commands and live monitoring to focus on specific models.
Enhanced burn rate calculations with activity density for sparse usage, improving projection accuracy.



Documentation

Added a comprehensive BUILD.md file with detailed instructions for building, installing, developing, and troubleshooting the project locally.



Style

Updated the live monitoring header to reflect broader usage monitoring beyond just tokens.



Chores

Updated the package name for global installation and testing purposes.

title: feat(blocks): add cost-based and model based live monitoring support
bodyText:
feat(blocks): add cost-based live monitoring with -c/--cost-limit option
Add new cost limit functionality for live monitoring mode:

Add -c/--cost-limit argument supporting numeric values and "max" keyword
Implement cost-based progress bars and projections in live display
Add mutual exclusivity validation between token and cost limits
Support cost burn rate display ($X.XX/hour) instead of tokens/min
Add maxCostFromAll calculation to find highest cost from previous sessions
Update live rendering to show cost-focused displays when cost limit is active
Maintain backward compatibility with existing token-based monitoring

Technical changes:

Add parseCostLimit() function mirroring parseTokenLimit() logic
Extend LiveMonitoringConfig type with costLimit field
Update compact display mode to support cost limits
Add comprehensive test coverage for cost limit scenarios
Create BUILD.md with local installation and development instructions

Breaking changes: None - fully backward compatible
feat(blocks): add model filtering support with -m/--model option
Add CLI support for filtering usage data by specific Claude models in blocks command.
Supports both static and live monitoring modes with partial model name matching.
Changes:

Add -m/--model CLI argument accepting comma-separated model names
Update LoadOptions interface to include models filter
Implement model filtering in loadSessionBlockData with partial matching
Add model filtering to LiveMonitor for live mode support
Update LiveMonitoringConfig interface to pass model filter
Support partial matching (e.g., "sonnet" matches "claude-sonnet-4-20250514")

Usage examples:

ccusage blocks --model sonnet
ccusage blocks --model sonnet,opus
ccusage blocks --live --model sonnet


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for cost-based usage limits and live monitoring, allowing users to set and track cost limits in addition to token limits.
Introduced model filtering capabilities, enabling users to filter usage data and statistics by specific model names.
Added per-model cost limit functionality and detailed per-model usage breakdowns.
Improved activity-aware projections for more accurate usage forecasting.



Documentation

Added a comprehensive build and installation guide, including troubleshooting tips and descriptions of new features.



Chores

Updated the package name to "hg-ccusage" for distribution.

Minor Changes


#â€‹9796 ba69586 Thanks @â€‹simonabadoiu! - Browser Rendering local mode


#â€‹9825 49c85c5 Thanks @â€‹ReppCodes! - Add support for origin_connection_limit to Wrangler
Configure connection limits to Hyperdrive via command line options:

--origin-connection-limit: The (soft) maximum number of connections that Hyperdrive may establish to the origin database.



#â€‹9064 a1181bf Thanks @â€‹sdnts! - Added an event-subscriptions subcommand


Patch Changes


#â€‹9729 1b3a2b7 Thanks @â€‹404Wolf! - Set docker build context to the Dockerfile directory when image_build_context is not explicitly provided


#â€‹9845 dbfa4ef Thanks @â€‹jonboulle! - remove extraneous double spaces from Wrangler help output


#â€‹9811 fc29c31 Thanks @â€‹gpanders! - Fix unauthorized errors on "containers images delete".


#â€‹9813 45497ab Thanks @â€‹gpanders! - Support container image names without account ID


#â€‹9821 a447d67 Thanks @â€‹WillTaylorDev! - Preview Aliases: Force alias generation to meet stricter naming requirements.
For cases where CI is requesting Wrangler to generate the alias based on the branch name, we want a stricter check around the generated alias name in order to avoid version upload failures. If a valid alias name was not able to be generated, we warn and do not provide an alias (avoiding a version upload failure).


#â€‹9840 7c55f9e Thanks @â€‹dario-piotrowicz! - fix: make sure that the experimental remoteBindings flag is properly handled in getPlatformProxy
There are two issues related to how the experimental remoteBindings flag is handled in getPlatformProxy that are being fixed by this change:

the experimental_remote configuration flag set on service bindings is incorrectly always taken into account, even if remoteBindings is set to false
the experimental_remote configuration flag of all the other bindings is never taken into account (effectively preventing the bindings to be used in remote mode) since the remoteBindings flag is not being properly propagated



#â€‹9801 0bb619a Thanks @â€‹IRCody! - Containers: Fix issue where setting an image URI instead of dockerfile would incorrectly not update the image


#â€‹9872 a727db3 Thanks @â€‹emily-shen! - fix: resolve Dockerfile path relative to the Wrangler config path
This fixes a bug where Wrangler would not be able to find a Dockerfile if a Wrangler config path had been specified with the --config flag.


#â€‹9815 1358034 Thanks @â€‹gpanders! - Remove --json flag from containers and cloudchamber commands (except for "images list")


#â€‹9734 1a58bc3 Thanks @â€‹penalosa! - Make Wrangler warn more loudly if you're missing auth scopes


#â€‹9748 7e3aa1b Thanks @â€‹alsuren! - Internal-only WRANGLER_D1_EXTRA_LOCATION_CHOICES environment variable for enabling D1's testing location hints

title: fix(live-monitor): Fix live token count and align default token limit behaviour with docs
bodyText:
Fixes #288 and #298.
For #288, the issue was simply that the getTotalTokens function was not being used in the live monitor; so the incorrect number was being displayed.
For #298, the issue was that the default behaviour specified in the docs is that the live monitor uses the max token limit from previous blocks. However, the actual default behaviour was to specify no limit at all, and therefore fall back to just showing a 10% progress bar (L226, _live-rendering.ts) for usage and 15% progress bar (L303, _live-rendering.ts).
Before fix:

After fix:

There are some alignment issues in the rendering around the progress bars. However, I do not feel that fixing that issue is necessary for this fix, as it is simply a result of the current formatting choices.
The code for this PR was hand-written, not AI-generated. :-)

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Improved consistency in handling token limit inputs, so missing or empty values are now treated the same as specifying 'max'.
Enhanced reliability of token count calculations by using a centralized method for determining total tokens.

title: fix(blocks-json): Fix total token count calculation to include cache
bodyText:
Fixes #274
Total token count was being calculated incorrectly, and has now been updated to use the correct function.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Refactor

Improved how total token counts are calculated for session blocks, centralizing the logic for better consistency.

title: Using UTC year/month/day in data-loader
bodyText:
#311

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Improved date formatting to accurately handle timezone information, ensuring correct display of dates with UTC or offset timestamps.
Enhanced date output options with support for single-line and two-line formats.

title: fix(live-monitor): Fix layout collapse in narrow terminal width
bodyText:
The branch name is fix-issue-172, but this does not fix issue #172.
(It is a confusing branch name because I tried to create a PR out first that fixes another issue found while working on this issue. Sorry!)
Changes


In live monitor, to avoid breaking borders when the terminal is narrow, do the following:

The progress bar is shortened.
Margins are reduced.
Token counts, etc. are shortened using k.
More information is displayed on two lines.



In live monitor, re-render the terminal when it is resized.


Screenshots


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

The display now adapts dynamically to available space, adjusting column layouts and formatting for improved readability.
Token counts and usage details automatically switch between full and short formats based on space constraints.
Session, usage, and projection sections intelligently reformat to fit content, using multi-line layouts when needed.



Improvements

Progress bars and text elements resize dynamically for better alignment and presentation.
The interface updates immediately upon terminal resize for a more responsive experience.

title: perf: optimize file reading with mtime filtering (up to 10x faster)
bodyText:
When using --since flag, pre-filter files based on modification time before reading contents. This provides significant performance improvement for users with extensive usage history.
Changes:

Add mtime pre-filtering to skip files modified before --since date
Optimize getEarliestTimestamp to stream only first 10 lines
Add comprehensive documentation explaining why this is safe

Performance: up to 10x faster when loading data with --since flag
Why this is safe: Claude Code is append-only, so mtime always reflects when data was last added. If mtime < since date, the file genuinely has no data after that date.
ğŸ¤– Generated with Claude Code

Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Added a new document detailing recent performance optimizations and testing instructions.


Performance Improvements

Enhanced file loading speed by pre-filtering files based on modification time when using the --since flag.
Reduced memory usage and improved efficiency by streaming files to extract timestamps instead of reading entire files.


Chores

Introduced a script to benchmark and compare performance between tool versions.

title: fix: correct session id identification from path
bodyText:
Summary
The code claude implemented for fetching the session ID is incorrect.
Previously it looked in ~/.claude/projects/project-name/session-id/xxx.jsonl, however the actual storage location is ~/.claude/projects/project-name/session-id.jsonl
This change updates the path logic to identify the session by the UUID and properly detect the project name. Worth noting that the paths from the projects folder to the jsonl are relative, so the projectPath is really just the name of the folder, not the full absolute path. Since this isn't displayed at the moment, I figured that was fine.
This was done directly in github web editing, I expect there to be a CI failure or two. Right now this is untested, but I plan on using this in the anthropics/claude-code-action workflow to print out the costs at the end of the workflow.
Testing

Prior to change with latest upstream, session ID was the project name
npx -y --package ccusage@latest -- ccusage session --breakdown

[info] [ccusage] Loaded pricing for 1247 models

title: feat: add message count column to blocks table display
bodyText:
Summary

Add a new 'Messages' column to the blocks table display showing the count of entries in each block
Update the detailed active block view to show message count
Ensure all table rows (including gap, remaining, and projected rows) align properly with the new column

Motivation
Claude's billing model includes message-based limits in addition to token limits. For example, the Max 20x plan has a limit of ~900 messages per 5-hour session. Without visibility into message counts in the blocks report, users cannot track their usage against these limits effectively.
Changes

Added 'Messages' to table headers in src/commands/blocks.ts
Added block.entries.length as message count in regular block rows
Updated gap rows, remaining rows, and projected rows to include empty placeholders for proper column alignment
Added message count display in the detailed active block view
The MCP server already includes entries count in JSON output, so this change only affects the table display

Testing

Tested locally with bun run start blocks to verify the new column displays correctly
Ran bun run test to ensure no existing tests were broken
Ran bun run format and bun typecheck to ensure code quality

Example Output
The blocks table now shows:
Block Start                Duration/Status  Models             Messages  Tokens      %        Cost
12/09/24, 3:54:29 PM      (28m)            claude-sonnet-4       42      12,345    2.5%    $0.0370
12/09/24, 4:25:00 PM      ACTIVE           claude-sonnet-4      204      45,678    9.1%    $0.1370

The detailed active block view (--active flag) now includes:
Current Usage:
  Messages:         204
  Input Tokens:     35,678
  Output Tokens:    10,000
  Total Cost:       $0.1370

title: feat!: exclusive CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR mode for isolated directory usage
bodyText:
Summary
This PR introduces an exclusive mode for CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR that allows users to isolate their usage reports to specific directories only, rather than aggregating across all available Claude installations.
Closes #360
Motivation
Currently, when CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is set, ccusage aggregates data from both the specified directory AND the default directories (~/.config/claude and ~/.claude). This can be confusing when users want to analyze usage from a specific Claude installation in isolation.
This change makes the behavior more intuitive:

When CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is set: Use ONLY those specified paths
When CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR is not set: Use default paths as before

Changes

Modified getClaudePaths() in src/data-loader.ts to return early when environment paths are found
Updated JSDoc to reflect the new exclusive behavior
Added development workflow documentation with justfile for easy maintenance
Documented shell function patterns for convenient directory switching

Usage Examples
Users can now create shell aliases for different Claude installations:
# Function for default directories only
ccuse() {
    CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR="" ccusage "$@"
}

# Function for specific installation
ccuse-work() {
    CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR="$HOME/.claude-work" ccusage "$@"
}

# Usage
ccuse daily          # Shows only default directories
ccuse-work daily     # Shows only work directory
Breaking Changes
None. This change maintains backward compatibility:

Users not setting CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR see no change
Users setting CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR get more predictable, isolated results

Testing
Tested locally with multiple Claude installations:

Verified exclusive mode shows only specified directory data
Confirmed default behavior unchanged when env var not set
Validated --instances and --project filters work correctly

Development Workflow
Added a justfile for contributors who want to maintain local modifications:

just update - Full workflow to sync with upstream
just rebuild - Quick rebuild after changes
Supports easy rebasing of local changes on upstream updates

Screenshots
Before (aggregated):
CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR=/custom/path ccusage daily
# Shows data from: /custom/path + ~/.config/claude + ~/.claude

After (exclusive):
CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR=/custom/path ccusage daily  
# Shows data from: /custom/path ONLY


Summary by CodeRabbit


Bug Fixes

Improved handling of configuration directory selection by prioritizing environment variable paths exclusively and providing clearer error messages when invalid paths are specified.



Chores

Updated logic for determining valid configuration directories for a more predictable and user-friendly experience.

Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.26.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#â€‹10016 c5b291d Thanks @â€‹emily-shen! - Interactively handle wrangler deploys that are probably assets-only, where there is no config file and flags are incorrect or missing.
For example:
npx wrangler deploy ./public will now ask if you meant to deploy a folder of assets only, ask for a name, set the compat date and then ask whether to write your choices out to wrangler.json for subsequent deployments.
npx wrangler deploy --assets=./public will now ask for a name, set the compat date and then ask whether to write your choices out to wrangler.json for subsequent deployments.
In non-interactive contexts, Wrangler will error as it currently does.


#â€‹9971 19794bf Thanks @â€‹edmundhung! - Improved script source display on the pretty error screen


Patch Changes


#â€‹9800 3d4f946 Thanks @â€‹helloimalastair! - remove banner from r2 getobject in pipe mode


#â€‹9910 7245101 Thanks @â€‹dario-piotrowicz! - make sure that the ready-on message is printed after the appropriate runtime controller is ready
fix the fact that when starting a local (or remote) dev session the log saying Ready on http://localhost:xxxx could be displayed before the runtime is actually ready to handle requests (this is quite noticeable when locally running dev sessions with containers, where the ready message currently gets displayed before the container images building/pulling process)


#â€‹10031 823cba8 Thanks @â€‹vicb! - wrangler and vite-plugin now depend upon the latest version of unenv-preset


#â€‹10032 154acf7 Thanks @â€‹dario-piotrowicz! - add support for containers in wrangler multiworker dev
currently when running wrangler dev with different workers (meaning that the -c|--config flag is used multiple times) containers are not being included, meaning that trying to interact with them at runtime would not work and cause errors instead. The changes here address the above making wrangler correctly detect and wire up the containers.


#â€‹9988 7fb0bfd Thanks @â€‹penalosa! - Correctly label mtls remote bindings warning

title: Add weekly usage command
bodyText:
This adds a weekly usage command. (#375) From what I read, it wasn't exactly clear how they were going to set the usage window so I added code that makes it work for both Sunday and Monday. When we know how the windows are going to work we can update it. I tested both though and they both seem to work.
With it set to Monday:

With it set to Sunday:

For now I left it set to Monday because I think that'll most likely be the day they reset it since it's the first day of the working week.

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added weekly usage reporting, allowing users to view aggregated token usage and costs by week.
Introduced a new CLI command to generate weekly usage reports with options for JSON or table output, filtering, and detailed breakdowns.
Enhanced data aggregation to support grouping usage by arbitrary time buckets (weekly or monthly).
Added support for weekly usage data type across calculations and validations.
Introduced configurable start day of the week for weekly reports.



Bug Fixes

Ensured tests run consistently in the UTC timezone.



Chores

Updated development dependencies to earlier versions for improved compatibility.

title: Adds ClaudeLog badge and Claude Code Resources  section
bodyText:
Summary by CodeRabbit

Documentation

Added a new badge for ClaudeLog in the README header.
Introduced a "Claude Code Resources" section with links to advanced guides and best practices for Claude Code, including topics like plan mode, ultrathink, sub-agents, agent-first design, and configuration guides.

Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.26.1
Compare Source
Patch Changes


#â€‹10061 f8a80a8 Thanks @â€‹emily-shen! - feat(containers): try to automatically get the socket path that the container engine is listening on.
Currently, if your container engine isn't set up to listen on unix:///var/run/docker.sock (or isn't symlinked to that), then you have to manually set this via the dev.containerEngine field in your Wrangler config, or via the env vars WRANGLER_DOCKER_HOST. This change means that we will try and get the socket of the current context automatically. This should reduce the occurrence of opaque internal errors thrown by the runtime when the daemon is not listening on unix:///var/run/docker.sock.
In addition to WRANGLER_DOCKER_HOST, DOCKER_HOST can now also be used to set the container engine socket address.


#â€‹10048 dbdbb8c Thanks @â€‹vicb! - pass the compatibility date and flags to the unenv preset

Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.27.0
Compare Source
Minor Changes


#â€‹9914 a24c9d8 Thanks @â€‹petebacondarwin! - Add support for loading local dev vars from .env files
If there are no .dev.vars or .dev.vars.<environment> files, when running Wrangler or the Vite plugin in local development mode,
they will now try to load additional local dev vars from .env, .env.local, .env.<environment> and .env.<environment>.local files.
These loaded vars are only for local development and have no effect in production to the vars in a deployed Worker.
Wrangler and Vite will continue to load .env files in order to configure themselves as a tool.
Further details:

In vite build the local vars will be computed and stored in a .dev.vars file next to the compiled Worker code, so that vite preview can use them.
The wrangler types command will similarly read the .env files (if no .dev.vars files) in order to generate the Env interface.
If the CLOUDFLARE_LOAD_DEV_VARS_FROM_DOT_ENV environment variable is "false" then local dev variables will not be loaded from .env files.
If the CLOUDFLARE_INCLUDE_PROCESS_ENV environment variable is "true" then all the environment variables found on process.env will be included as local dev vars.
Wrangler (but not Vite plugin) also now supports the --env-file=<path/to/dotenv/file> global CLI option. This affects both loading .env to configure Wrangler the tool as well as loading local dev vars.



Patch Changes


#â€‹10051 0f7820e Thanks @â€‹nikitassharma! - Add support for custom instance limits for containers. For example, instead of
having to use the preconfigured dev/standard/basic instance types, you can now
set:
instance_type: {
  vcpu: 1,
  memory_mib: 1024,
  disk_mb: 4000
}

This feature is currently only available to customers on an enterprise plan.


#â€‹10149 e9bb8d3 Thanks @â€‹vicb! - fix require("debug") in nodejs_compat mode

title: refactor: use Intl.DateTimeFormat for date formatting
bodyText:
Summary
This PR refactors date formatting functions to use the standard Intl.DateTimeFormat API instead of manual string construction.
Changes

Replace manual date parsing with Intl.DateTimeFormat in formatDate() function
Use formatToParts() for flexible formatting in formatDateCompact() function
Explicitly use UTC timezone to avoid timezone-related issues

Benefits

More robust timezone handling: Explicitly using UTC prevents timezone-related bugs
Standards-compliant: Uses native browser/Node.js APIs instead of manual string manipulation
Better performance: Native implementation is typically faster than JavaScript string operations
Future-proof: Ready for internationalization if needed in the future

Technical Details

en-CA locale is used for YYYY-MM-DD format (Canadian English uses ISO 8601 date format)
formatToParts() allows extracting individual date components for custom formatting
All existing tests pass without modification, confirming backward compatibility

Testing

âœ… All existing tests pass
âœ… Date formatting output remains unchanged
âœ… No breaking changes to public API

title: fix: use local timezone for date grouping instead of UTC
bodyText:
Summary
This PR fixes an issue where usage data was being grouped by UTC date boundaries instead of the user's local timezone, causing data to appear on incorrect dates.
Fixes #413
Caused by #409
Problem
When using ccusage, usage data was being grouped incorrectly based on UTC time rather than the user's local timezone. This caused confusing results where:

Usage at 20:00 local time (MDT) would appear on the next day's report
Daily summaries didn't align with when users actually used Claude Code
Users in timezones behind UTC would see their evening usage shifted to the following day

Example
A user in MDT (UTC-6) using Claude Code at 8:00 PM on August 3rd would see that usage reported as August 4th, because 8:00 PM MDT is 2:00 AM UTC the next day.
Solution
Removed the hardcoded timeZone: 'UTC' configuration from the Intl.DateTimeFormat instances in data-loader.ts. This allows the date formatters to:

Use the system's local timezone by default
Respect the TZ environment variable if users want to override it
Group usage data by local date boundaries as users would expect

Changes

Removed timeZone: 'UTC' from dateFormatter
Removed timeZone: 'UTC' from datePartsFormatter
Updated comment to reflect local timezone usage

Testing

All 253 existing tests pass
Verified that usage data now groups correctly by local date
Confirmed that the TZ environment variable can still override timezone if needed
Linting and type checking pass without issues

Backward Compatibility
This change makes the date grouping more intuitive and correct for users. The data itself is unchanged - only the grouping/display is affected. Users who need UTC grouping can still achieve it by setting TZ=UTC.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Dates are now displayed and grouped according to your local timezone instead of UTC, providing a more intuitive experience for users in different regions.

title: feat: add timezone option for date grouping
bodyText:
Summary

Added --timezone/-z option to all commands for configurable date grouping
Users can now specify any valid IANA timezone (e.g., UTC, America/New_York, Asia/Tokyo)
Default behavior remains unchanged - uses system timezone when not specified

Why this change?
Following up on #414, this PR adds proper timezone support as a command-line option rather than relying on environment variables. This provides a more flexible and user-friendly way to control date grouping across different timezones.
Changes

Added timezone option to shared command arguments
Updated formatDate and formatDateCompact functions to accept timezone parameter
Modified all commands (daily, monthly, weekly, session, blocks) to pass timezone option
Updated MCP server to accept timezone parameter
Added comprehensive tests for timezone functionality
Updated documentation with timezone usage examples

Examples
# Use UTC timezone for consistent reports
ccusage daily --timezone UTC

# Use specific timezone
ccusage daily --timezone America/New_York
ccusage monthly -z Asia/Tokyo

# Default behavior (system timezone)
ccusage daily
Test plan

 All existing tests pass
 Added new tests for timezone parameter functionality
 Manual testing with different timezones
 Documentation updated


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for specifying a timezone in daily, weekly, monthly, session, and blocks usage reports via a new --timezone (-z) command-line option.
Date grouping and formatting in reports now respect the selected timezone, allowing for consistent reporting across different regions and use cases.



Documentation

Updated user guides and README with instructions, examples, and use cases for the new timezone support feature.
Clarified configuration environment variable documentation.

title: feat: add locale option for date/time formatting
bodyText:
Summary

Add `--locale` option to all ccusage commands for customizable date/time formatting
Default to `en-CA` locale for ISO date format (YYYY-MM-DD) and 24-hour time
Support automatic 12/24 hour time switching based on locale (e.g., en-US uses 12-hour, ja-JP uses 24-hour)

Changes

âœ¨ Add `--locale`/`-l` option to shared command arguments with default value `en-CA`
ğŸ“ Update `formatDate` and `formatDateCompact` functions to accept locale parameter
ğŸ”§ Pass locale option through all data loading functions
ğŸŒ Update blocks command to use locale for time display (`toLocaleString`)
ğŸ§ª Add comprehensive tests for locale functionality
ğŸ“š Update README and configuration documentation with locale examples
ğŸ”Œ Update MCP server to accept locale parameter

Examples
```bash
Use US English locale (12-hour time format)
ccusage daily --locale en-US
Use Japanese locale (24-hour time format)
ccusage blocks --locale ja-JP
Use German locale (24-hour time format)
ccusage session -l de-DE
Default behavior (uses en-CA for ISO format)
ccusage daily
```
Test plan

 Run `bun run format` - All files formatted correctly
 Run `bun typecheck` - No type errors
 Run `bun run test` - All 257 tests pass
 Test with different locales manually
 Review documentation changes
 Test MCP server with locale parameter


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for a --locale option to customize date and time formatting in reports and outputs, allowing users to specify regional formats (e.g., en-US, ja-JP, de-DE).



Documentation

Updated user guides and README to explain the new --locale option, with examples and use cases for internationalization and regional preferences.

title: fix: off-by-one compact date formatting
bodyText:
Suggested fix for issue #433.
formatDateCompact is being given a date in YYYY-MM-DD format that has already been converted to the local time zone. Constructing a new Date from that string interprets it as UTC, which causes an off-by-one error for users at a negative offset from UTC.

Summary by CodeRabbit

Bug Fixes

Improved date formatting to ensure dates in "YYYY-MM-DD" format are displayed correctly according to local time, preventing timezone-related discrepancies in the formatted output.

title: feat: add LOG_LEVEL environment variable support
bodyText:
Summary

Add support for LOG_LEVEL environment variable to control logging verbosity
Provides a clean way to control log output without breaking existing CLI interface
Added -l short flag for locale option, -n for blocks sessionLength

Changes

Added LOG_LEVEL environment variable support in logger.ts
Values: 0 (silent), 1 (warn), 2 (log), 3 (info/default), 4 (debug), 5 (trace)
Changed blocks command sessionLength short flag from -l to -n to avoid conflicts
Added -l as short flag for locale option (common CLI convention)
Updated documentation in README.md and CLAUDE.md

Test Plan
âœ… Tested LOG_LEVEL=0 (silent mode) - only shows table output
âœ… Tested LOG_LEVEL=3 (info mode) - shows normal logging
âœ… All existing tests pass
âœ… Type checking passes
âœ… ESLint formatting applied
Usage Example
# Silent output (only show data tables)
LOG_LEVEL=0 ccusage daily

# Debug mode for troubleshooting
LOG_LEVEL=4 ccusage monthly

Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Added support for controlling log output verbosity via the LOG_LEVEL environment variable.
Introduced a shorthand -l flag for the locale argument in CLI commands.



Improvements

Changed the short option for the sessionLength argument to -n for clarity and consistency.



Documentation

Updated documentation to describe the LOG_LEVEL environment variable and provide usage examples.



Chores

Upgraded the "lint-staged" development dependency to the latest version.

title: feat: add statusline command for Claude Code status bar integration
bodyText:
Summary

Adds new  command for Claude Code status bar integration
Shows real-time usage metrics in a compact single-line format
Beta feature with color-coded burn rate indicators

Features
Core Functionality

Session Cost Tracking: Displays current conversation session cost
Daily Total: Shows cumulative spending for the current day
Block Status: Tracks active 5-hour billing block with remaining time
Burn Rate: Color-coded cost per hour indicator (green/yellow/red)
Model Display: Shows active Claude model at the beginning

Technical Implementation

Reads session data from stdin as JSON (Claude Code hook protocol)
Uses picocolors for color-coded burn rate indicators
Compact output format optimized for status bar display
Includes test scripts and dummy test file for easy testing

Output Format
Test Plan

 Test with dummy JSON input via ğŸ¤– Opus | ğŸ’° $0.00 session / $0.00 today / $30.57 block (3h 43m left) | ğŸ”¥ $37.50/hr
 Verify color-coded burn rate indicators work correctly
 Confirm session cost calculation from session ID
 Test with no active block scenario
 Run format and typecheck
 Test with actual Claude Code integration

Documentation

Added comprehensive documentation in
Updated README with new command
Added test scripts to package.json

Notes
This is a Beta feature. Future enhancements planned:

Custom format templates
Configurable burn rate thresholds
Additional metrics display options


Summary by CodeRabbit

New Features

Introduced a new "Statusline Integration" (Beta) for displaying a compact, real-time status line with Claude Code usage statistics.
Added a CLI command to show the status line and updated documentation with setup and usage instructions.


Documentation

Added a detailed guide for the new status line feature, including setup, output examples, and troubleshooting.
Updated usage examples and feature list in the README to reflect the new status line integration.


Tests

Added a test fixture for simulating status line input and new test scripts for the status line feature.

title: fix(statusline): correct session ID handling for accurate cost tracking
bodyText:
Summary

Fixed session cost tracking by using `session_id` directly from hook data instead of extracting from transcript path
Added `sessionIdInLog` field to distinguish between path-derived and JSONL-logged session IDs
Updated statusline command to properly match sessions using the logged session ID

Problem
The statusline command was incorrectly extracting session IDs from the transcript path, which didn't match the actual session IDs stored in JSONL data. This caused session costs to always show as 0 or N/A.
Solution

Use `hookData.session_id` directly instead of path extraction
Track both `sessionId` (from path) and `sessionIdInLog` (from JSONL) separately
Match sessions using `sessionIdInLog` for accurate cost calculation

Test Plan

 Test statusline command with active session
 Verify session costs are correctly displayed
 Confirm daily costs still work correctly
 Check that N/A is shown when session data is unavailable


Summary by CodeRabbit


New Features

Enhanced session tracking by distinguishing between two session IDs: one derived from the file path and one from the log data, improving session matching accuracy.



Bug Fixes

Improved handling of missing session cost data, now displaying "N/A" when unavailable.



Documentation

Updated documentation to clarify the session tracking mechanism and the distinction between session IDs.

title: fix(statusline): correctly load session costs using actual session IDs
bodyText:
Summary

Fixed session cost calculation in statusline command to use actual session IDs from hook data
Added new loadSessionUsageById() function to properly locate and load specific session JSONL files
Improved test coverage with vitest environment mocking

Problem
The statusline command was incorrectly trying to extract session IDs from transcript paths instead of using the session_id field directly from hook data. This caused session costs to not be displayed correctly.
Solution

Created dedicated function loadSessionUsageById() that searches for JSONL files by their actual session ID (filename)
Updated statusline command to use the session_id from hook data directly
Added comprehensive tests with vitest environment mocking and proper cleanup
Updated documentation to clarify the naming confusion between project directories and actual sessions

Test Plan

 Run bun run test - all tests pass
 Run bun typecheck - no type errors
 Run bun run format - code is properly formatted
 Test statusline command with actual Claude Code hooks

title: refactor: extract common data loading logic to reduce code duplication
bodyText:
Summary

Extracted shared file loading, parsing, and deduplication logic into a new `_common-loader.ts` module
Consolidated common utility functions (filtering, sorting, aggregation) in `_common-loader.ts`
Reduced ~430+ lines of duplicate code across data loading functions
Improved maintainability and consistency across data loading operations

Changes
Initial Refactoring

Created new internal `_common-loader.ts` module with `loadCommonUsageData` function
Refactored `loadDailyUsageData` to use common loader
Refactored `loadSessionData` to use common loader
Refactored `loadSessionBlockData` to use common loader
Removed duplicate helper functions (`isDuplicateEntry`, `markAsProcessed`)

Additional Consolidation (Latest Commit)

Moved `filterByProject`, `filterByDateRange`, and `sortByDate` to `_common-loader.ts`
Moved `aggregateByModel`, `calculateTotals`, `createModelBreakdowns` to `_common-loader.ts`
Moved `extractUniqueModels` and `aggregateModelBreakdowns` to `_common-loader.ts`
Removed all duplicate implementations from `data-loader.ts`
Fixed imports to use direct imports instead of dynamic imports
Corrected type imports for `ModelBreakdown` type

Impact

Before: Multiple functions with 88-92% code similarity, ~430+ duplicate lines
After: Centralized common logic, minimal duplication remaining (only necessary differences)
Result: More maintainable codebase with single source of truth for data operations

Test plan

 All existing tests pass (265 tests)
 Linting passes (`bun run format`)
 Type checking passes (`bun typecheck`)
 Verified with `similarity-ts` that code duplication is significantly reduced
 No functional changes - all commands work identically

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
Summary by CodeRabbit


Refactor

Centralized loading, filtering, deduplication, and cost calculation of usage data into a shared module for consistency and maintainability.
Simplified daily, session, and session block data loading by delegating core processing to the new common loader.



Chores

Enhanced error handling and resource management during usage data processing.

Release Notes

cloudflare/workers-sdk (wrangler)
v4.28.1
Compare Source
Patch Changes


#â€‹10130 773cca3 Thanks @â€‹dario-piotrowicz! - update maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession config argument (to allow callers to specify an environment)
Before this change maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession could be called with either the path to a wrangler config file or the configuration of a worker. The former override however did not allow the caller to specify an environment, so the maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession API has been updated so that in the wrangler config case an object (with the path and a potential environment) needs to be passed instead.
For example, before callers could invoke the function in the following way
await maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession(configPath);
note that there is no way to tell the function what environment to use when parsing the wrangle configuration.
Now callers will instead call the function in the following way:
await maybeStartOrUpdateRemoteProxySession({
	path: configPath,
	environment: targetEnvironment,
});
note that now a target environment can be specified.


#â€‹10130 773cca3 Thanks @â€‹dario-piotrowicz! - fix getPlatformProxy not taking into account the potentially specified environment for remote bindings


#â€‹10122 2e8eb24 Thanks @â€‹dario-piotrowicz! - fix startWorker not respecting auth options for remote bindings
fix startWorker currently not taking into account the auth field
that can be provided as part of the dev options when used in conjunction
with remote bindings
example:
Given the following
import { unstable_startWorker } from "wrangler";

const worker = await unstable_startWorker({
	entrypoint: "./worker.js",
	bindings: {
		AI: {
			type: "ai",
			experimental_remote: true,
		},
	},
	dev: {
		experimentalRemoteBindings: true,
		auth: {
			accountId: "<ACCOUNT_ID>",
			apiToken: {
				apiToken: "<API_TOKEN>",
			},
		},
	},
});

await worker.ready;
wrangler will now use the provided <ACCOUNT_ID> and <API_TOKEN> to integrate with
the remote AI binding instead of requiring the user to authenticate.


#â€‹10209 93c4c26 Thanks @â€‹devin-ai-integration! - fix: strip ANSI escape codes from log files to improve readability and parsing


#â€‹9774 48853a6 Thanks @â€‹nikitassharma! - Validate container configuration against account limits in wrangler to give early feedback to the user


#â€‹10122 2e8eb24 Thanks @â€‹dario-piotrowicz! - fix incorrect TypeScript type for AI binding in the startWorker API
